reviewText:
"The Theory of Everything" (2014 release from the UK; 122 min.) brings the story of Stephen and Jane Hawking. As the movie opens, we are reminded that we are in "Cambridge, 1963". Stephen and Jane are going to university in Cambridge, and they meet at a party. It is immediately clear that there is a spark between them, but Stephen is either shy or ignorant about women. Fortunately Jane does not give up on him. Meanwhile, it is not long (15 min.) in the movie that we see Stephen starting to struggle with an oncoming illness. He is eventually diagnosed with Lou Gehrig's disease and is given 2 years to live. Despite the stern warnings of Stephen's father that "this is going to be a heavy defeat', Jane decides to push on with Stephen. All the while, Stephen is also working towards his Ph. D. in physics. To tell you more would spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first and foremost, this does not strive or is intended to be a biopic of Stephen Hawking, but instead it brings the story of Stephen and Jane. This is only confirmed when in movie's end titles, I noticed that the script is based on Jane's memoir ("Traveling to Infinity: My Life with Stephen"). Second, much has been made about the acting performances so let's get to that: yes, the rumors are true: Eddie Redmayne, previously best known from My Week With Marilyn and Les Miserables, will blow you away as Stephen, reminding me of Daniel Day Lewis' defying role in My Left Foot all those years ago. Watch Redmayne collect many an award in the upcoming awards season. But equally brilliant is Felicity Jones as Jane. I saw Jones recently in "Breathe In", where she was completely miscast as a high school exchange student (she is 30 in real life). Here, she get a mature role that seems tailor-fit for her. Surely this will get noticed as well in the upcoming awards season. Third, the movie's production and photography is brought with richness and lushness. Fourth, the orchestral score, courtesy of composer Johann Johannsson, is as sentimental as it is delightful. If there is one negative comment that I have about the movie, it is that the scientific side of Stephen Hawking's academic work is all but left untouched. I am not the wiser now than I was before the movie as to why Hawking's theories are so important and set him aside from many other thinkers and scientists of his generation. A missed opportunity in my opinion although as stated before, I don't think the movie ever intended to explore that aspect in detail.

The movie opened recently at my local art-house theater here in Cincinnati. The Sunday early evening screening where I saw this at was attended okay but not great, which really surprised me. Seeing that the movie has been garnering a lot of positive buzz in recent weeks, I would've thought that people would come in droves to see this. All that aside, the bottom line is "The Theory of Everything" is a wonderful and tender look at Jane and Stephen Hawking's relationship, and the two lead performances will dazzle you. "The Theory of Everything" is HIGHLY RECOMENDED

In the memory of Stephen Hawking, I wanted to give this movie 5 stars and the fact that I suck as a movie critic.  This movie does a great job explaining the struggles of Stephen Hawking in his early years, and how he rose to be the person that he became before his passing day.  I wouldn't recommend this movie if you are a strict theist as it does question the existence of God; but if you can approach this movie with an open mind, then I think you'll appreciate what this movie has to show.  The casting for this movie and all the production teams were all perfect in my opinion, I feel as though they did a great job depicting the life of Stephen Hawking...

This movie is brilliant on several levels... the actors, the director, the choice in where to have words and then the lack of words in profound moments of realization in their lives and how the actors expression told what words could not express;  the presentation of how they dealt with the unique circumstances that made up their lives; the way the ending led back to the beginning of such spectacular happenings to these people.  I was in awe at this whole presentation and how it was presented.  Such a refreshing  story of their complexity put to film is a rarity... showing the beauty of their character in dealing with their unique situation and the way love flowed throughout their lives... it is so wholesomely told. It is a story of the human spirit and how we can overcome adversity and deal with 'sticky' moments and still show how wonderful humanity is meant to be.  It is indeed a movie for the human spirit with a Godly woman and an atheist; it was intriguing.

Stunning! I rarely write reviews, but this movie literally changed me. Its tone kind of reminded me of 'Amadeus', another favourite of mine.  I have always been a Stephen Hawking fan, but seeing this absolutely made me fall in love with him even more. I was absolutely taken by Eddie Redmayne's performance in this, and I will forever think of him as Stephen.  It was a very well deserved Oscar indeed. The acting and casting was immaculate. I literally sob every time I watch it, it is so very moving...
Some people were clearly wishing for a more detailed explanation of his physics theories, and although those are somewhat discussed in the film, they are not the focus for a good reason: We are instead looking at Stephen's and Jane's lives, and at his perseverance, at the inspiration that he has been to humanity, at his courage to endure and to continue living with a wonderful sense of humour and disposition in spite of living with ALS. Perhaps his book provides better details about his theories. At any rate, this is a beautiful story, and it is very much worth watching and buying. It is a beautiful piece, absolutely indispensable in any DVD collection.

I study physics and mathematics and I'm just finishing up my bachelors degrees. I've read pieces of Hawking' s dissertation and I was astounded how accurately they represented it (those are actual pictures of it!). The performances were breathtaking from every actor and actress. It feels amazing to have a movie not shy away from the real genius behind science; math. Hawking says it best himself, "there is no *believing* in physics".

It deeply saddens me he has recently passed away. It destroyed any small hope I had of meeting the man. He is responsible for much of my love for science and my academic career.

I may never be as humble, intelligent, successful, or lucky as him, but I will surely try. He was a brilliant man, and will always be my hero. I am humbled to have shared the same timeline of humanity with him.
I hope his legacy continues to inspire other students of science.

Theories to prove the existence of black holes, God or intelligent alien life in the vast universe can't hold a candle to the unproven theories behind why a good woman will sacrifice all for the love of one man, regardless of his Intelligence Quotient, physical abilities and/or flaws.

The acting and musical score In "The Theory of Everything" are brilliant. Everything you see and hear in this movie, whether it be a couple's hands caressingly touching, the crippling effects of ALS or the fearful look in the eyes of those watching the physical changes ALS brings upon the body of a loved one, add to the care and concern of the viewer.

Mrs. Jane Hawking is the hero and teacher in this movie. She's showing us what the life of a loving wife, primary caregiver and loyal friend to a man the likes of world-renowned physicist Stephen Hawking looks and feels like.  I hate to say it, but the genius Stephen Hawking only need look back on the love and loyalty of his wife Jane in order to see and believe that yes, there is a God looking over his life and that of his children. The question is not are there other forms of life in the universe, but are there other forms of love. For what is life without love, but survival of the fittest. Wow, did I say that!

Regardless of what you believe concerning Stephen Hawking or the universe, this movie carries with it a deep and respective understanding of what it means to be human. Carefully crafting Hawking's life, from his marriage to Jane, or the development of his theories about the universe we live in, "The Theory of Everything" paints a picture of love, loyalty, pain, brokenness, and eventually, a strange yet haunting fulfillment of hope. No doubt the message of this movie is powerfully represented: that human kind, though one primate among many, can find hope in the theory that there are no limits to our humanity, just as there are no limits to the stars. Though many disagree with this, myself included, I can't argue with the fact that this movie argues its point well in a cinematic masterpiece that moves you emotionally, and for some, intellectually as well. And they use Hawking's story as a case-in-point example. Despite his disease, he lived well beyond the life expectancy that was branded on his life, lived a fulfilled and happy marriage, and became the successful Ph. D he dreamed of one day being. And it was perhaps his own victory against his struggles that brought him to the conclusion that there is no limit stamped on humanity. The film depicts Stephen and Jane's struggle against his disease, as they both try to keep their family together, and he tries to get his Ph. D. In a very raw depiction of the two, the viewer gets a very real sense of what they actually went through and what it cost them, but also what they gained.
As a film, I don't think I have ever seen, nor ever will see a movie so well acted. Eddie Redmayne was absolutely phenomenal, and I didn't doubt for a second that he wasn't Hawking himself. His physical acting, as well as his emotional acting were truly awe inspiring, acting at its finest. Felicity Jones and the other major players of the film were incredible as well, easily playing upon the emotions of there characters, staying in character flawlessly, and making every second of the movie believable.
Technically, this film was easy to watch, and well directed, and was entertaining all the way through. Though I disagree with Hawking, I am hard pressed to think of another biographical drama that beats "the Theory of Everything". Excellent film...please do watch!
Parental guide: sexuality is limited to conversational implications of an appropriate nature, as well as a brief look at a Penthouse magazine towards the end. Cursing is countable one hand, and thematic details, though not appropriate for a child, are good for anyone above the age of 12-13. Depending of your worldview, also be ready to have a talk with your child about the ideas put forth in this movie about the universe.

A theory of everything, is a brilliant story of loss and survival. As you follow the life of Stephen Hawking(Eddie Redmayne), you learn, and feel the loss and betrayal. If you ever need to cry about something, this movie is for you. As you watch Jane(Felicity Jones) fall in love with Stephen, then leave since it becomes to hard, your heart will break into a million peices. At the end of the movie you see the dramatic transformation in hawking, not just physically, but mentally. If you don't have a soul then this movie is not for you, but if you ever want to feel so grateful for everything in your life,then look no further. This movie is a work of art, and a true award winner.

Eddie Redmayne really makes the movie, and Felicity Jones . . . oh my goodness, Fantastic Beasts meets Rogue One.  Felicity didn't quite age herself enough by the end of the movie, but she did a great job through most of it and was convincing enough as a caring, loving wife who dealt with the situation as best she could.  What a sad story, though really.  I didn't know much about Stephen Hawking's love life, so I wasn't expecting the story to end the way it did.  I only wish the relationship began a little less abruptly.  They met at a party, she gave her his number, but we didn't get a chance to see what initially attracted her to him and him to her.  They simply started dating, but the courtship moved along quickly.  Before I knew it, I was absorbed by Redmayne's ability to transform himself, the way realistic portrayal of his struggles, and touching relationships that developed.

Yes, this is the theory of everything by THE Stephen Hawking still alive genious the one who cannot speak or move but only can conversation through his machine like computer keyboard.
Still he is the living legend in science.
His love and sceience life is in this movie.
Some romantic, some very sad and depressing.
Done by a very delicate actor Eddie Redmayne we all know him from movies like <THE DANISH GIRL><LES MISERABLES><MY WEEK WITH MARYLINE>.
He finally won the best actor from Oscar with this movie. But not many people noticed this film properly.

It is not healthy telling the story but as I may,..
When Stepen figures out his illness during studying at Cambridge when very young, he even tried to avoid the most beautiful girl he just met.
The most beautiful girl is the right word.
But it was her who came to him this time and she approached and said even if your life will be only 2 years left, I want to marry you.
They got married.
But as someone said, love don't last forever.
Their marriage didn't last forever.
You know when a guy becomes a totally crippled it's not a life anymore and for a wife it is not fair to be together anymore.
More over, for him the love is totally gone and everything becomes just annoying. His temper is no longer sweet or even he is not thankful for her.
What can she do?
When there is a guy who is servicing for church appears, there is no denying that she is in love with him although she has two children already.
Even there is a roumour that their third child is not their's.
When Stephen is having another attack and this time he lost his voice, it becomes a total black in his life. He seems like no more life left in him.
For her it is a hell too.
And then there appears this a bit old but sweet woman nurse. She is madly admiring Stephen and everywhere Stephen goes he wants her to go too.
One day he tells his wife that he wants to be with her.
Naturally they have to be apart.
Even now the first wife and Stephen are just friends they each have different marriage.
But as we all know Stephen is a living legend with not able to speak, move or expose his feeling without his computer.
But it is truely magical what he have done so far.
This movie is not afraid of showing what has he go through in his life.
It was not all rainbows and sunshines.
There are some ugliness things happened and they showed them all.

The actors did a very good job and Eddie Redmayne has a dynamite performance. The story line left much to be desired. A feeling of disconnect with the writing and the joy of science is obvious. After reading a few of Hawking's books and biography this film just didn't feel right. If you like Hawking and love Science there is another film with Benedict Cumberbatch titled "Hawking" that gets the feel of Hawking's Love for science and intellectual triumphs more accurately portrayed.

As a computer specialist I know that all computers are called "Turing machines" not because he built one (America built a much better one for the Manhattan Project) but because he had provided a mathematical proof that showed that such machines were possible.  The movie does not explain the complete extent of Alan Turing's genius.  Most people give credit to Churchill or Roosevelt or some other well known historical figure for defeating Nazi Germany.  The truth is that NONE of their accomplishments would have been possible without Alan Turing.

This Movie is a MUST SEE.

I knew enough about Stephen Hawking, but after seeing The Theory of Everything, I wanted to know everything.

It's the story of a brilliant man and the woman who loved him. It's a love story, and I'm a sucker for love stories. The Theory of Everything is based on a book by Jane Hawking about her life with Stephen Hawking. From that spark of love at first sight, to when his disease first hits, to how they cope with it in the years to come, you want to be there with them through it all.

Part of what makes this film great are the performances by Redmayne and Jones. Both actors clearly studied the people they were based on and it shows through how they portray their speech and physical quirks. It's so good I actually believed I was watching Stephen Hawking and his wife at times.

There's one very particular scene, I don't know if it's based on a real event or not, but Stephen looking through his sweatshirt into a fire and becoming inspired was an amazing scene. The way it was shot and what was showed, he didn't have to say a single word but you completely understood the metaphor of what exactly was happening. I had to watch that scene a few times because I get goosebumps every time.

I want to thank Jane and Stephen Hawking for sharing their love story with us. Recommended.

The movie begins with both attending prestigious Cambridge University in England. Hawking is a cosmologist studying for his Ph. D. in physics. Jane Wilde is studying French and Spanish Arts and working for a Ph. D. in Medieval poetry of the Iberian Peninsula. He is diagnosed with a motor neuron disease known as Lou Gehrig's disease. He eventually loses all ability to control muscle movement and given a two year life expectancy. Hawking wanted to prove with a mathematical equation that time had a beginning; time is not infinite. He also demonstrated that, although, black holes (at the center of galaxies) have an extreme gravitational pull that visible UV light cannot escape, they do emit heat radiation (not visible to the human eye). Over eons, black holes evaporate away until they disappear.

The Theory of Everything is the journey that Stephen and Jane Hawking took based on the book by Jane Hawking, Traveling to Infinity: My Life with Stephen. This is a beautiful story of love, passion and sacrifice.  Astrophysics Stephen Hawking (played by Eddie Redmayne) is brilliant and his scientific passions of discovery can not be stopped. As a Cambridge student Stephen met the love of his life, Jane Wilde (played by Felicity Jones).

As they began to experience life and each other, Stephen begins to notice that he is unable to perform everyday simple tasks like picking up a pen or walking. It was later discovered that Stephen had Lou Gehrig's Disease and was diagnosed with only a few years to live. Despite this diagnosis and the complications that he began to experience he and Jane marries and have three children.

As the disease began to take its toll on Stephen he continues on with his scientific passions.  Jane had to play dual roles from the caretaker of Stephen and helping him with his written reports to being solely responsible for the care of the children. For me, The Theory of Everything provided two sides of the coin 1) no matter what obstacles occurs in life, you can accomplish anything and 2) the choices of sacrifice that you make, should harbor no regrets.

This film is based on the book MY LIFE WITH STEPHEN HAWKING by Jane Hawking.  As such, the angle in which the story proceeds is a love story between the physicist and his girlfriend & subsequent wife.  For the most part, the research of his life as well as the writing of his 1st book (A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME)  are in the background.  In the forefront are the more human issues of the scientist's life, such as his struggle with ALS and raising his family as best he could under the circumstances.

Even more than the above issues, the focus of the film are on Jane's travail in having to cope with a husband who, albeit brilliant, is also in deteriorating health.  His speech is so slurred that only she & a few other close friends can understand him B4 he's unable to speak @ all.  Thankfully, a software whiz from the U.S. (CALTECH, if I remember correctly?) offers him a speech synthesizer which gives his thoughts a familiar computer voice that most of us are now acquainted with.

Eddy Redmayne bears a striking resemblance to Hawking in the film and he is believable as someone who is afflicted with ALS.  The movie gives us an insight into the day-to-day issues that Hawking has had to deal with when the most basic things such as eating and moving around become arduous tasks.

For anyone who is interested in the life of an influential scientist, this is a must-see movie.  It is about a man who attempts to comprehend the mysteries of the cosmos whilst confined to a wheelchair:  that in & of itself is inspiring!!  Also, people who enjoy this movie will be apt to enjoy the movie INFINITY with Mathew Broderick.  It, too, is about the love story involving a scientist ~ Richard Feynman.  In that case, it is his wife who is dying from ALS while he is working @ Los Alamos during the Manhattan Project days of WWII.  Both films are well worth your time & attention.

I suppose I was expecting a better movie based on all the accolades it received. With such high expectations it is difficult to not be a bit disappointed.

Redmayne does a fine job contorting his body, slurring his words and expressing emotion non-verbally, but Felicity Jones actually does a better job of acting as Jane. The movie really is about Stephen and Jane's relationship rather than his science which makes sense because that relationship enabled his genius to flourish. (A movie about the science would be a series on Nova.)  I am not, however, a fan of movies that attempt to compress decades of a life, or lives, into 2 hours. They invariably end up feeling shallow and unsatisfying. This is a fine movie and worth seeing - once. It is not a movie I will see more than once because there really is nothing in it that one misses the first time. There is no nuance, no complex message, no underlying theme to go back and ponder or re-examine.

Eddie Redmayne was awarded a well-deserved Academy Award for Lead Actor in a Movie with his performance as the legendary physicist and genius, Stephen Hawking CBE CH. As we all know, Stephen Hawking was a brilliant physics student until he was diagnosed with motor neuron disease or Lou Gehrig's disease with only two years to live. He married Jane Wilde and fathered three children. Despite the prognosis of two years later, he has defied the odds and is still very much alive although confined to wheelchair with a speaking box.

This movie is about marriage, defying the odds, and miracles. Stephen and Jane's marriage evolves over the decades. Jane's relationship with Jonathan is complicated. Although Stephen shouldn't be patronized for his lack of physical abilities, he is quite capable of making mistakes. His relationship with eager nurse Elaine Mason led to a marriage that ended in divorce. Stephen and Jane still remain friends and parents and grandparents to their grandchildren.

Stephen's story is very much Jane's story as well. In watching this film, you can't help but see their marriage survive and endure the odds. Stephen Hawking was honored with a CBE (Commander of the Order of the British Empire) and the prestigious Companion of Honour (only 65 living recipients are at one time). Stephen has declined knighthood. Ironically, Eddie Redmayne gets a real visit to Buckingham Palace to be awarded the OBE (Officer of the Order of the British Empire).

Eddie Redmayne has mastered Stephen's mannerisms for this film. Felicity Jones mastered the personality of Jane Wilde Hawkings. Maxine Peake does a notable job as Elaine Mason, his nurse and future second wife. The film doesn't bring up the relationship except to end the Jane and Stephen's marriage. Stephen asks Elaine to accompany him to America.

The DVD has the film; the making of Hawkings; and several deleted scenes including Stephen being awarded the CH (Companion of Honour) with an actress to play Queen Elizabeth II.

I wasn't expecting the Theory of Everything to MOVE me so much emotionally!  It's about the struggles of Stephen Hawking (played by Eddie Redmayne) first discovering out the hard way by passing out on university campus back in 1962 that he has a neurological disorder and will lose all the strength in muscles.  Even worse he was supposed to be dead in 2 years.  If I was Stephen in that situation I would've been devastated.  The doctor should have mentioned this news more understandingly but I guess in the early 60's compassion wasn't top priority when it came to certain things.

Luckily Stephen falls in love with a young intelligent woman (Felicity Jones) who's willing to do everything in her power to keep Stephen alive knowing full well he's a genius.  At first it's recommended by her friends to avoid Stephen since he's a weird college guy, but due to Stephen's persistence he eventually gets the girl he desires.  Keep in mind Stephen's healthy at this point and able to walk around normally since the relationship develops before the neurological disorder happens.  Stephen sort of has to chase after the girl he desires since she has a way of shying away at first, but she turns out to be an extremely important person in helping Stephen get through his new condition (which is interestingly also known as Lou Gehrig's disease).  An interesting/humorous moment when British Stephen tries explaining to his fellow students he has the same disease as a famous baseball player, but they aren't sure why he's mentioning baseball.

While some of Felicity's ways later on are quite questionable (she falls in love with Charlie Cox's character even though she has a few kids with Stephen and understands more than anybody his constant struggles day in and day out, which makes her pretty lousy) she also does a tremendous job providing encouragement to Stephen to help him through his daily struggles while the marriage is fresh.  So Felicity still deserves to be respected in my opinion for all that she did in helping Stephen, even if she began to fall for another man.

It's important to note that the Theory of Everything focuses on the emotional side of Stephen Hawking instead of his genius theories (such as his wish to prove that everything in the universe can be explained by a simple black hole theory).  Oh sure we see Stephen as a college kid attending astronomy classes and becoming one of the most intelligent students in his class with theories that were criticized by his professors at first but later accepted when they began to realize his theories make sense.  However the subject of his expertise isn't touched upon as much as one would think in this movie.

Instead the Theory of Everything mainly focuses on Stephen getting married to his wife, their lives in a new house in the country with kids, Felicity's affection for Charlie (that Stephen must have known about though wasn't stated), the tear-jerking moments showing Stephen struggling to stand up and be as normal as possible (of which there are MANY of these, making for one tough film to handle) to Stephen eventually getting the technology to turn his electric wheelchair into a computer-based communication system which is what we associate with Stephen these days.  I sort of thought Stephen played a part in inventing such a technology but maybe I was wrong.  Either way it's surprise that not only were electric wheelchairs available back in the 60's, but that a voice communication system was made not long after.

Oddly I never realized such a technology existed back in the day, however we're never sure exactly what period of time Stephen is able to speak using this voice technology because the movie has a way of moving several years into the future but they really saying or showing when it happens, and the characters don't exactly age a whole lot either so it's hard to know when these events really occurred.  At least I understood near the end we were many years after the 70's but I couldn't tell you what year.

Some things weren't quite explained and were left for us to interpret.  Such as the redheaded lady played by Maxine Peake brought over to be a teacher to Stephen after he loses his muscle moving abilities completely.  It wasn't stated during the film whether the two developed a relationship even though it was clearly leaning towards one.  I suppose they explain this at the very end before the credits role, but while the movie's happening it's really subtle.  I guess Felicity knew.  Plus Stephen invited Maxine for an American trip and things were explained more clearly then.  Still not 100% clearer however.  More should have been explained about Stephen's theories to possibly clear up this one.

Also while giving a presentation, Stephen sees a girl drop a red pen on the floor.  We then see Stephen stand up, walk over, pick it up and give it to her.  I'm pretty sure he simply imagined doing this and wasn't physically able to but you never know.  Also the third kid Stephen and his wife had.  It was implied by Felicity's mother that it might actually be Charlie's kid because she must have known Felicity and Charlie were getting along a little too well while running around in the backyard with Stephen, and Felicity storms out of the kitchen embarrassed shortly after.  So the two had feelings, but was that third kids theirs?

The ending was really sad.  I don't know what it was, but watching the constellations, the universe and stars developing so enchantingly while the orchestrated music played made me think just how incredibly sad it is that we have to grow older and eventually die, so I honestly cried while watching this scene... cried a lot.  Must be one of those days.

Overall this movie does a tremendous job teaching us what Stephen Hawking's life was like as a college student and how much he had to endure.  The doctors originally said he only had 2 years to live when his first diagnosis happened, so to watch him barely survive a couple major near death experiences later on was really crazy.  I think we all knew he survived, but how many of us understood everything he had to face?  Just unbelievable what this man had to go through.  Also the movie does have one humorous moment- when Maxine holds up a dirty magazine after Stephen apparently ordered one and flips through the pages much to his liking, because she knows what guys are interested in, haha.  Overall really good movie.  Perhaps more focus on Stephen's groundbreaking theories would have made this a 5-star film.

This is a stunning and memorable British biographical romantic drama that touches the heart, the soul and the mind. This is based on the memoir Travelling to Infinity: My Life with Stephen by Jane Wilde Hawking.

This is a spectacular movie of history, education and the ultimate exploration and understanding of the life of one of the greatest minds of all time. You get to go along with Hawking's life and love and passion and ultimate struggle. I have always been fascinated with Stephen Hawking. I have read all his books and I am in utter amazement at the man and of his genius. It's wonderful seeing a personal side, the emotional reality. The tense struggle. The visionary filmed form.

This is lovingly put together. One of the best examples of a film about not only the person in biographical plot, but its about the loved ones involved. A stunning portrait of this great man. This is possibly one of the best acting performances I have seen in a very long time. A movie of perfection put together in that you the watcher can see the love, passion and fascination put into this film about this genius. Most of all its about the emotional reality of the struggle and the depth of this challenging disease and the hardships loved ones and the one going through it has to bare.

The movie showcases the beautiful and rough parts of Hawking's life to a crystal clarity. The man that brings this part to life is a young man that I have absolutely fallen in love with throughout his acting career. This part as Hawking's, gives you the viewer what the art form and mastery of acting is, Eddie Redmayne aces this part and deserves all the accolades for this performance. The next Golden Ticket of acting perfection goes to the beautiful Felicity Jones who plays Jane, Stephen's wife and companion. Jones is so emotionally great in this part. She and Redmayne are gifted. Loved both of them.

A flawless example of how to create a wonderful film. I have already watched it twice. I really loved the experience. To anyone and everyone that wants to explore or experience a thought provoking example of brilliant acting and explore the exploration of this amazing man and story then look no further than The Theory of Everything.

A passionate and beautiful and sad at times amazing film. I shed tears at times. Jane Wilde Hawking's was a wonderful and strong woman for Stephen. She stood by him for many, many years and treated him with beauty. Felicity Jones captures her perfectly. The whole movie expresses itself with a passionate heart.

Eddie Redmayne and Felicity Jones shine together. Perfect chemistry. A very emotional experience that showcases itself into a masterpiece of acting reality. Great direction by James Marsh. He captures the love, the struggle and the wonderment of the story into a filmed form.

If I had to choose a flaw to this amazing movie it would be the co-stars not being able to showcase there amazing talent. This movie is filled with phenomenal actors such as the extraordinary David Thewlis who acted in one of my favorite films of all time Mike Leighs Naked. The beautiful and amazing Emily Watson. The wonderful amazing Harry Lloyd. The brilliant Simon McBurney. The perfect Adam Godley. Just an amazing cast of co-stars. The craftsmanship of each of these stars shined just having their names in the small parts that they showcased. The movie held its power with an amazing cast of stars and co-stars in their small parts. The whole movie, creates an acting art form.

Masterpiece acting, brilliant story, Stunning direction, Perfection of cinema.

A Brief History of Time has sold more than 10 million copies worldwide.

Now 72 years old, Stephen has no plans to retire and continues to seek a Theory of Everything.  He declined the offer of a knighthood from the Queen.

 Jane has her Ph. D. in Medieval Spanish Poetry.  She and Jonathan are happily married.

 Jane and Stephen remain friends and now have 3 grandchildren.

The above is printed on-screen at the very end of this excellent British biographical romantic drama film based on the memoir Travelling to Infinity: My life with Stephen by Jane Wilde Hawking (2007).

This movie deals with Janes relationship to her ex-husband, theoretical physicist and cosmologist Stephen Hawking, his diagnosis of ALS or motor neuron disease (also called Lou Gehrigs disease), and his success in physics.

Heres what the real S. Hawking says about this movie:

Its a human interest story.  Success against the odds.  It shows that disability can be no handicap...It reflects our struggle to bring up three children in normality despite my disability.

I liked the way this film blended science with romance, quite a unique combination.

Here is the dialogue of one of my favorite scenes when Jane and Stephen are still dating:

Jane: What about you?  What are you?
Stephen: Cosmologist, Im a Cosmologist.
J: What is that? [That is, what is Cosmology?]
S: It is a kind of religion for intelligent atheists.

Eddie Redmaynes performance as Stephen Hawking is mesmerizing.  This is what the real S. Hawking said about Redmaynes performance:

I think Eddie Redmayne portrayed me very well.  He spent time with ALS sufferers so he could be authentic.  At times, I thought he was me.

Felicity Jones as Jane Hawking gives a strong performance.  This is what the real J. Hawking says about Jones performance:

Felicity was absolutely superb.  I was very impressed with Felicity because she came [to see me] several times and we talked a lot.  And, then when I saw her on the screen, I thought Oh, my goodness.  Thats me.  Because she had captured my mannerisms.  And not only that, but I could recognize my modes of speech through Felicityit was a beautifully played part.

I also enjoyed the background music.  It has a dainty precision with a scientific quality to it.  This music definitely enhances each scene.

This movie has earned back more than eight times its budget (of fifteen million dollars).  It also captured five Academy Award nominations (with Redmayne winning for best actor).

Finally, the DVD (the one released in 2015) has three interesting extras.  It is from one of these extras that I obtained the above quotes by the real S. and J. Hawking.

In conclusion, this is a tremendously moving and inspirational movie, a bittersweet love story, inflicted with tasteful good humor with superb performances from its two leads.  It shows how the love of a dedicated wife allowed the genius of her severely disabled husband to bloom!!

(2014;  2 hr excluding end credits;  20 scenes;  wide screen)

<<Stephen PLETKO, London, Ontario, Canada>>

Eddie Redmayne does a marvelous of "becoming" Hawking physically and, since his illness soon took his ability to speak clearly and then away completely, that can be the reason I didn't see a lot of the interior man. OK, I get it, he's an amazing theoretician. Nevertheless, in this portrayal he seems to me to be a person oblivious to the cost of his illness on others. About halfway through I realized that his genius was so central that those around him, especially his wife and kids, had no real life other than attending to him. I was honestly amazed how long she stayed faithful and committed to him when he seemed to take so much and give so little back. It truly just seemed like another "faithful wife sacrifices all to genius husband", and I think we've seen enough of those already.

This movie was beyond fantastic. Redmayne's acting was superb, he had to have studied Stephen Hawking in great detail and for a very long time, as what we see him go through - the gradual, then quickening decline of his health and muscle control - is mind boggling. The story starts out so sweetly but quickly gets into Stephen's illness and my partner and I both cried all the way through the movie - both because of the sadness of his condition, the depression and exhaustion of Jane, the resulting side romances and the joys and sadnesses from those, etc - but also because Stephen Hawking is portrayed as SO understanding of their situation, financially, romantically, medically and he does his best to keep Jane happy. Hawking is also portrayed as having such a positive attitude (most of the time) and a great wit and humorous side, that laughter through tears is frequent while watching. The soundtrack is beautiful and really adds to the intensity of the emotions. We both work in medical fields and see people in various states of decline regularly, plus I have a partner who died of AIDS in 1994, having been intubated and then with a tracheostomy in the last few months - and he never talked again, either - so the movie hit close to home.

This movie does not fully go into everything the Hawkings endured, nor does it explain everything quite on spot.

POSSIBLE SPOILER ALERT!!!!

What would have been REALLY helpful, while watching the movie, is if they'd have at least placed year markers throughout the movie, to help us keep track of when different things happened. We know Stephen and Jane met in 1963 and married shortly afterwards but as to when he had to finally use the wheelchair permanently, when did he receive his Doctorate, when was his pneumonia/tracheostomy done, when did Stephen receive the computerized voice (that finally gave him so much independance back)? Things like the years of his children's birth, he and Jane's separation and subsequent divorce, his marriage to Elaine, and the date of his final award/speech (shown in the film) would have been great.

After watching this movie (and finally getting my eyes dry enough to read), I read Professor Hawking's Wikipedia page to learn more (a book unto itself - and, I'm not a physicist so understood little of his work) - and this movie, quite honestly, barely scratches the surface - although he is now in his 70s and I believe this movie ended roughly in the late 90s. Of course, this movie was based off of Jane's book, Travelling to Infinity: My Life with Stephen. As such, it's a movie from her POV and about their life together, not all his accomplishments and, spanning roughly 4 decades, there is only so much time in a movie to show only so much. I am actually purchasing Jane's book now (she did write another before this but it was written earlier, while in a darker place in their relationship) because I found their story so fascinating, I want to learn more!

I am giving this movie one star because it was very slow and boring, and because the movie only hinted at events in Steven Hawking's life and told the story so poorly that I needed to look it all up to understand what happened, which was extremely disappointing.

The actor who played Steven Hawking looked exactly like him and did an amazing job.
But I didn't see any chemistry between him and the actress who played Jane, his wife.

SPOILER ALERT..MAYBE.

This movie hinted at events in Steven Hawking's life, but was not clear.
I actually had to look him up to understand the ending.

Exactly what was he studying?
What theories did he come up with and what did they mean?
What was his book about?

This man is paralyzed.
He is as helpless as a newborn. He cannot do anything for himself.
He can only communicate because someone was kind enough to donate a talking machine to him.
He can only move around because an electric wheelchair was donated to him.

In his condition, this man manages to :

(1) Get married
(2) Finish school and become a professor
(3) Father a first, a second, and a third child
(4) Write a book and get it published
(5) Have an affair
(6) Leave his wife and move to America
(7) Divorce his wife and remarry
(8) Give lectures and continue a successful career
(9) Divorce his second wife
(10) Continue working into his 70s with no intentions of retiring
(11) I don't know what else, because the movie was unclear and I didn't spend that much time on Google

How many totally healthy men could accomplish these things?

The movie was completely unclear that Steven Hawking had an affair, left his wife, and married his nurse.

It was so unclear that I had to look it up on Google to understand exactly what happened.

All that we see in the movie is that Steven tells Jane that he is going to America, and she says that she did her best, but he never says that he is leaving her for another woman or that he is divorcing her, so it can be assumed that he is simply going to America for his career and that he is coming back to his wife. The writers of this movie seemed to think that the viewers would already know the story, so they didn't bother to detail it.  If I knew the whole story, then why would I want to watch the movie?

The movie absolutely never shows that Steven Hawking had an affair, fell in love with his nurse, left his wife, divorced his wife, remarried, and later divorced his second wife. What is the point of telling a story about a man's life if major facts are omitted?

I felt so bad for Jane. She was a loyal wife to a paralyzed husband.  When she married him, she believed that he only had two years to live. She had his three children and raised them plus cared for her helpless husband and put her own career on hold. She fell in love with another man, but did not have an affair, out of respect for her husband, and yet, her paralyzed husband actually had an affair and left her. I was glad to hear that Jane later married Jonathan, which was not explained in the movie.  Jane later wrote a book, which was also not mentioned in the movie.

The story of Steven Hawking's life should have been an amazing and inspiring movie if the writers had detailed it and told it properly and completely.

Formulaic and ultimately unconvincing -- uh-oh, another disease of the month film -- about the life of Stephen Hawking, based on a book written by his wife.  The actors are excellent, but you still don't come away with a sense of what is so exceptional about Hawking.  And watching Eddie Redmayne disintegrate before your eyes, at times mumbling incomprehensibly, is quite depressing.  It comes across as contrived and Hollywoodized -- a woman sacrificing for her disabled husband.  And although we are privy to sugar-coated scenes from their courtship and romance, there still isn't any real sense of the characters beyond cutouts here, and a few pronouncements about physics and the universe.  It's all nicely acted and photographed, with a gushing musical score, and there are heartfelt moments.  But in the final analysis, it comes across as saccharine, manipulated and contrived.  Emily Watson, who only appears briefly in the film, steals the show -- she is beyond superb, and vastly superior to the material.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

I must confess to having mixed feelings about "The Theory of Everything," which covers the life of Stephen Hawking, from his days as a young graduate student afflicted with ALS (called "motor neuron disease" in England) to the present time as a celebrated scientist who communicates via a computer and is confined to a wheelchair in an immobile state, for the rest of his days.

The film's scenarist, Anthony McCarten, wisely does not attempt to explain Professor Hawking's scientific theories in great detail but is more interested in depicting Hawking's sad physical decline along with the relationship with his first wife, Jane Wilde Hawking, who wrote the book the film is based on.

The goal is to hold Hawking up as an inspiration to all of ushere was a man who was given two years to live and is still alive in his seventies. Not only is he alive but is an international figure, having made great contributions to the field of physics and wrote a worldwide, best-selling book, explaining his theories in more simplified form, so the ordinary man on the street could understand his extremely difficult concepts.

The film has a beautiful score with performances that seem quite believable. Eddie Redmayne shines as Hawking in an extremely difficult, physically-demanding role. Still there's another voice in me that asks should Hawking really be viewed as an "inspiration?" Of course he is but on the other hand, if you were a genie and could take away Hawking's disease along with his super-intelligence, I believe that Hawking wouldn't hesitate to cast off his "brains" so he could walk again. What I am trying to say is that despite the inspiration, his life is still a tragedy.

In the end, is there really enough here to create a full-length feature film? Or would a documentary serve as a better vehicle to illustrate the Hawking story? The "sad decline" which I alluded to before is quite ably illustrated here for all to see. There's not much drama in that nor the eventual dissolution of Hawking's marriage to Jane, which was an inevitable resolution given the overall tragic circumstances.

"The Theory of Everything" is a beautiful tribute to a man who made something out of his life despite a harrowing disability. In that respect, it accomplishes what it sets out to do. We all can be inspired by such a tale but ultimately, Hawking's accomplishment is no "triumph." The dream sequence where Hawking gets out of his wheelchair and picks up a pen while attending a conference reminds us that such a simple act trumps any of the afflicted scientist's intellectual accomplishments which is decidedly akin to nothing more than a Pyrrhic Victory.

Intolerable tragedy in the presence of genuine love. Professor Hawkings, a famous, clear-thinking atheist, perhaps found an understanding of his wife's God in her all-too-human love of him. The scene where they realize their marriage is over breaks your heart. All the performances are exemplary, but Eddie Redmayne's channeling of Stephen Hawkings is nothing short of miraculous. A tender movie, a jewel shining light on the lives of a family facing outrageous adversity with courage, and kindness.

This is a wonderful movie about the life of Stephen Hawking, chiefly from the personal side of his life.  It begins in 1963 and tries to hit all the high points -- including a number of his scientific achievements -- for the next 40 or so years.  There are written biographies about him and undoubtedly they can fill in more of the facts; certainly some of them will give more details about his scientific achievements.  But, for what it is, this movie is as good as any I've ever seen about a scientist.  A documentary would certainly be better for the scientific details, but I'm glad they took the effort to make this movie.  A good movie has the ability to show the personal side every bit as well as a documentary, ofttimes better.  Thanks to the cast and crew for a great job.

Somewhat slow at times but overall a very interesting movie.  I'm not going to go into details about the movie and end up spoiling anything for anyone potentially interesting in watching it.  But there are some key things to note about this movie.

1.  Don't expect an entirely factual story.  I'm sure most is based on reality, but it did seem they had to take fictional twists on certain events to make a better movie.
2.  Don't expect a typical love story.  But it was a love story nonetheless.
3.  Don't expect a movie that focuses on his scientific achievements.  Instead, it focused on how his life was affected by this disease and how he was still able to achieve so much.  Its also about the huge sacrifices his wife made and how much she did to support him.

Ultimately, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie.  I honestly thought I would be bored to tears but I kept watching the movie and only felt there were just a few slow points in the story.

Eddy Redmayne was absolutely phenominal in the role of Stephen Hawking.  Although I enjoyed the film, it was at times had to distinguish what was being discussed because of the accents (to us Americans) and volume.  I was hoping for a bit more about Mr. Hawking himself and his accomplishments, not as much of the relationship between the two characters.  Still in all , an excellent film.
Amazing performance by Eddie Redmayne.  A well-deserved oscar.

This is my pick of best picture of the year.  Focusing on the the personal life of renowned British physicist and cosmologist Stephen Hawking and his wife, Jane, the film explores the difficulties and ambiguities of intimate relationships.  A perfunctory internet search indicates that the film did not fully deal with, but gave strong hints of some of the more distressful aspects of this love relationship between a brilliant, extremely physically debilitated, and famous man and his able-bodied and also brilliant wife.  Eddie Redmayne justifiably won an Academy Award for his depiction of Hawkings suffering.  The great gift of the film is that it gives equal attention to the life of Jane (kudos to actress Felicity Jones) who genuinely loves Hawking, but when she courageously agrees to be his wife and caregiver they have no idea that he will live for decades.  The film gives comforting insight that there are many ways to make a relationship work.

This film is a biopic about brilliant physicist Stephen B. Hawking. Events of his life includes his personal struggle with the motor neuron disease throughout his life;the achievement that he made in theoretical physics; and his relationship and family life with his ex-wife Jane Wilde Hawking. The Theory Of Everything was directed by James Marsh and adapted by screenwriter Anthony McCarten from the memoir Travelling to Infinity: My Life with Stephen written by Jane herself. It stars Eddie Redmayne and Felicity Jones as Stephen and Jane respectively.

The movie starts with Stephen as a healthy active young man and a doctorate student at Cambridge wherein he meets fellow student Jane. Then he later was discovered to have a disease that will provide him limitations in terms of voluntary movement,control and breathing. Despite of it,he and Jane gets married to start a family life and he continues his work on physics with the study of time and universe. It focuses primarily on their relationship as well as the ups and downs that Stephen's condition had as he constantly deteriorate as the movie progresses but nevertheless continues to show the world that he is indeed one of the most brilliant minds in science despite of it.

While Science fanatics will definitely be somewhat left empty as the movie does not focus on Stephen's work,it still will be considered one interesting and brilliant film as we get to see the determination of one mind who never gave up on his mission in life despite the many challenges he faced brought about by the limitations of physical ability that was caused by his disease. Also,one will definitely empathize with the solid relationship between Stephen and Jane particularly the commitment of the latter to their marriage especially with the sacrifices she made for the former's sake. Finally,it is one film that was surely well written despite the fact that the theme on Stephen's professional life as a physicists is somewhat lacking given the attention of the film to his personal life particularly his relationship with Jane.

This should have won Best Picture in my view.  The performances were outstanding!  Eddie Redmayne really deserved the Oscar he won!  You get a real insight into the life of Stephen Hawking as well as what his friends and family endured and contributed to his life and successes.

Well done!! The true story of one of the most peculiar men in the world.

No question one the striking and permanent questions that humankind has ponders since the beginning of existence, put many different ways depending of what is known, is how the universe was formed. In the old days that was a no-brainer because of course God did the deed and that ended the question, perhaps. But when humankind put aside that part of the question the guys and gals who were still interested in how it was formed had a field day, and are still doing so waiting for the next big idea to take root. For now though people, or rather professional observers, physicists and astronomers, are hovering around the black hole theory and the rest of us are going along. And the film under review, The Theory of Everything, the bio-pic rather semi-bio-pic of the extraordinary physicist Steven J. Hawking based on a memoir by his ex-wife Jane goes a long way to acknowledging his efforts at pitching that theory to the scientific community.

Of course that is not the only part the story that gets played out here since, except for nerds and geeks and their hangers-on, a story about a guy and a scientific theory would be a snorer. What makes this films plotline extraordinary is that Hawking (played by Eddie Redmayne) plugged on while suffering the debilitating effects of motor neuron disease which almost took his life and did take his voice and some other functions. So even if you are a little weak on your late unlamented attempts at understanding high school physics you can still appreciate the human struggle against all odds to survive that this ordeal thrown his way. (He was not expected to live more than a couple of years back in the 1960s when he developed the disease but as of 2015 he is still with us, hats off.)

Better yet this film avoids the snorer problem that Hollywood dreads and which follows films about science guys by putting plenty of romance, even if awkward and geeky romance, in the story-line. Everybody can get into the boy-girl thing (or all the contemporary other relationship combinations which produce a romance) and wonder, star-gazing wonder if you like, how Hawking and his wife, Jane (played by Felicity Jones) got through the whole thing as well as they did, and for as long as they did. Wonder too if we are missing something in that star-gazing when we undercover stuff about the sex lives of those geeky physicists in this film. See this one.

There are very few in the modern world that are unaware of the determination and indeed brilliance of 'Stephen Hawking'
who, faced with severe adversity continued to amaze, this is his remarkable story as portrayed by 'Eddie Redmayne'
With the World at his feet, 'Simon' a Cambridge student is told at the age of just 21 that he has 'Motor Neurone Disease' an
illness that will rapidly immobilize him, his life expectancy just 2 years.
His Brain won't be affected by the illness, he will try to cram a life-times work into this short time, he wants to expand and
develop his theories of time, so much to discover so little time.
Whilst at Cambridge he had met and fallen for 'Jane' (Felicity Jones) despite knowing their time will be short, they decide to
marry, they have Children.
'Jane' becomes his rock and is supportive and understanding, though as time slips by their relationship will become complex.
Determination in the face of adversity.......he continues his studies and expands his conclusions into the mysteries of time
itself, however proving his theories will take time, time he doesn't believe he has, however he beats the odds and becomes
renowned for his writings World-Wide........his work continues to this day.
'Eddie Redmayne' gives a stunning and convincing award worthy performance.
The film is a frequently intense and an often emotional journey as we see 'Simon Hawking' defy all odds to continue his work
over the past 50 years..........he has an incredible and indeed certainly got - A BEAUTIFUL MIND
Whatever ones taste in films this one in my view is - A Must See.

Great acting by Redmayne and Jones.  Story is constricted by its biographical content and the need to arrive at a particular outcome.  One difficulty in the story is that the protagonist seems to be both about Jane (Hawking's first wife and author of the book from which the movie is derived) and Hawking himself.  So it's neither particularly about the struggle of a woman caring for a disabled genius, nor so much a story about a genius who becomes disabled and triumphs over odds, but sorta both.  That becomes a problem with the hints of Jane's affair with Jonathan, for one doesn't really know how to feel--do we understand because we're in her difficult world or do we condemn her because she'd agreed to care for Hawking and knew what she was getting into.  Overall, it reminds me of A Beautiful Mind, but not handled quite a deftly from a storytelling point of view.

An extraordinary performance of a wonderful human being.
Stephen Hawking is the most preeminent physicist since Albert Einstein with writings such as A Brief History Of Time. The movie instead of delving too much in his professional life, focus more on his personal life and his family which turned out to be the better story. I really felt that I got to know the man behind the superstar persona and his iconic synthesized voice. You go through a journey in which he had to live with ALS, a devastating disease which can kill quickly or slowly over many years. I wonder how many people would carry on after being told they had only two years to live. Yet he moved on and had a family and continued his work. Love for his work and family has sustained him which is captured well. There many lighter moments too, like the time he got his synthesized voice. In a Dr Who moment, he impersonated a dalek.
Moving on to the performances, Redmayne delivers a performance well worth the Oscar and BAFTA award. He his completely believable and genuine in his portrayal of Hawking. To add emphasis to that, Stephen Hawking himself has noted that it seemed that he was really looking at himself when he saw the movie. I even go as far to compare his performance to be on the level of Daniel-Day Lewis. Felicity Jones delivers a strong performance as his first wife, Jane. She shows a inner strength and anguish as she shoulders a heavy burden to raise a family, pursue her career and care for Stephen.
I hope one day he does find the Theory For Everything. That would be a marvelous and proper epilogue.

A well-deserved Oscar for Eddie Redmayne. I was expecting a great movie when I first reviewed it and I wasn't disappointed. I was very impressed by the story of one of the greatest minds in the history of the world, Dr. Steven Hawking. I highly recommend this to anyone.

Caught it on AD so I wasn't interested enough to see it while the Oscar buzz was on and turns out that I predicted my "OK" film review.  The love stories, yes there are more than one, are driven largely by the handsome leads, Eddie Redmayne, Felicity Jones and Charlie Cox.  Kudos to Simon McBurney for his small but memorable role as the ever so British and kind Dad.

While the story, moving at nearly warp speed, goes from a meet cute to "I am dying" as we are introduced to all the main characters and the relationships before the diagnosis.  It is the "relationship of everything" that makes this movie spin which I cannot discuss without spoilers.  I can say that Jane (Felilcity Jones) falls stalwartly in love, in a 40's kind of way (the movie is set in the 60's), after a brief and a little stiff romance.  The Hawking family scenes before and after the disease announcement are among the warmest of the entire film and reveal a very smart family where Jane is an equal.  The good looking and boyishly bashful Charlie Cox, ala Colin Firth, is pitch perfect in his performance.

The film was neither a love story, although a good deal of it is devoted to the relationships of the trio which later expand to include a fourth, nor a science story of one of the great minds of our time.

It is almost a cliche that actors playing characters with physical challenges receive award nominations, and Mr. Redmayne was no exception here either. The truly feel good moments in this film were nostalgic for the 60's era and its music and I supposed were aimed at a Baby Boomer audience.

He is simply amazing at  the showing the progressive disabilities of this disease. Felicity Jones pulls off her role as the long over-worked spouse without becoming a pathetic creature but as an admirable woman who tried very hard to make his life as 'normal' as  possible for as long as possible. All  this while raising 3 children and accomplishing her own PhD. It is uplifting and never dwells on what Prof. Hawking cannot do, only on the incredible things can and has. Doctors when they are confronted to a disease they do not know or understand are ready to tell you will die within two years. This film, this Stephen Hawking is the most brilliant proof that doctors' predictions, and alas sometimes their prescriptions, are useless and nonsensical. They can just not admit they do not know.

Stephen Hawking is also the proof that your body can become completely obsolete, nonreactive, dilapidated and yet your mind may keep all its power, and the first power man's mind has is to be able to choose between ending the suffering of the body before intended by nature or using his mind to its full potential till the end of time, till the natural end of his time.

As for the famous theory of the black holes, of the limitless universe in space and time, and of the big bang that starts from something that is not considered as being the beginning, which is obvious since it existed before the big bang otherwise there would not have been a big bang, I will not here discuss the few details I could discuss. For example that time is a human invention and that nature only contains duration. This is so true that we still have not been able to configure some time counting machine that would come to the perfect dimension of a second, minute, hour, day, month, year that would enable us to skip the leap years and other silly little corrections like that.

The fake debate about God or no God is just what it is a fake debate. If the universe is limitless it has no beginning point, hence it has no creator. If there is a creator somewhere we can always wonder the way Buddha used to wonder: but who in the cosmos created that God, and that opens a door that leads to so many other doors that there is no logic along that line. The myth that you can find the perfect mathematical equation that will demonstrate the big bang theory is what it is a myth that cannot anyway evade the fact that if the big bang and the universe can be described by mathematical formulas, then it is obvious this universe is logical, is rational. Can anything rational exist all by itself outside the brain of a sentient and rational being? And that cannot be man since man is so young in this universe. We can always say it is the result of the architecture of the universe and that architecture cannot stand one minute if it does not respect some balancing elements, etc.

And you see the result. My grandmother is turning over and over in her tomb and she is losing her last teeth because she is chattering with fear, she is shattered by fear.

I can very precisely explain the origin and the phylogeny of human language that started somewhere around 250,000 years ago because it is the product of a very clearly definable situation, but to look for an origin of the universe which implies the universe is not limitless, or to accept the idea that the universe is limitless which implies always is not quantifiable and forever really means forever, does not answer the question about where all that comes from.

Luckily the film avoided that level of theory and concentrated on the human side of this heroic suffering and brilliant inventiveness, though, after one rebuffing session with scientists that sees several men of science leaving the room in furor and anger before some Soviet scientist turned the wind around, it does not even hint at the fact there might be some serious objection against that theory because it is nothing but a theory, hence a model constructed by the mind of a man, the minds of a few men. Hence something that has to be taken as what it is: only a human representation of what man understands about the universe at one moment in time, one moment in man's history, and man's history is the basis of man's time.

Of course no one expects a film to give us the final truth about what we do not even know how to imagine.

Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

We were looking for a dual purpose movie that appealed to both my wife and myself. It basically did that but otherwise was a rather poor movie. After watching the movie we visited some websites chronically Steven's life the movie made a lot more sense. The chronology of events is rather vague. The audience has a hard time discerning what achievements are being made, what background events are transpiring, and even what period in time or how much time has elapsed as the movie progresses.  After watching the movie I got the impression that Steven did little more in his life than get a Ph. D. and sit at home.  Either read up on his life before watching, or watch without regard for the reality of the portrayal. I remember seeing a documentary on Discovery one time that was better than this.

More voices added to the accolades. We used to see Stephen Hawking arduously making his way across the Cambridge campus. I am grateful to have seen this exquisite film, beautifully written and acted, based on the memoir "Travelling to Infinity: My Life with Stephen," by Jane Wilde Hawking. Eddie Redmayne (also great in "Jupiter Ascending"), Felicity Jones, Emily Watson, and David Thewlis round-out a remarkable cast. In living with someone who suffers with disability and chronic pain, we found the vivid depiction of Stephen Hawking's decline in health particularly moving. A film not to be missed.

This is a good movie about the life of Stephen Hawking. It is more about his life at the university, marriages, family, and the progression of his disease.  He has Lou  Gehrig disease.  It is the story about a brilliant man trapped in a body that just would not cooperate with his mind. He refused to give up and struggled to still excel in using his intellect to teach others and prove his theories.  I enjoyed the film but you should know that the film is not about his scientific theories but his life.

The film had a special meaning for me in that my brother had a stroke and was paralyzed. He also was extremely intelligent and I saw him suffer in pain for many years while not being able to use his body. He too admitted that he felt trapped in a body that would not allow him to use his intellect to its maximum potential. When someone close to you has a problem like this you can really relate to the true meaning of life.

Stephen hawking is brilliant and I admire his work. I don't know how much Hollywood has changed the story but I found it entertaining and I rated it 4 stars.

This is primarily a love story.  The fact that it involves a very brilliant scientist makes it even more amazing.  His wife Jane also is portrayed as a very remarkable woman who not only was attracted to this nerdy man but even when confronted with the fact that he had a very progressive motor neuron disease still wanted to marry him.  It was incredible to watch as she raised three children and was also care-giver to Steven Hawking.  And the scene that really made an impact on me was when the choir director came to their house for dinner.  Because Steven at that point had difficulty speaking Jane was able to make the guest understand how quantum physics worked by using inanimate objects.  Truly she had to be not only formidable but have the intelligence to understand what her husband was doing in his work.

How Steven Hawking was able to communicate, get around, and still maintain his sanity and sense of humor was amazing.  He was diagnosed with a condition that  gave him a life expectancy of two years but nearly fifty years later he is still alive and making an impact on science.  The marriage broke up but lasted a good thirty years and both Jane and Steven found some happiness with other mates.

Eddie Redmayne definitely deserved the Oscar for his portrayal of Hawking----the speech, the gestures, the increasing immobility issues, and the humor.  Felicity Jones as Jane Hawking was also stellar in that role and I believe she was nominated for Best Supporting Actress.  The only issue I had with this film is that the background music in the beginning when they are at a party was too loud and it was hard to hear the dialogue, but otherwise it was an awe inspiring film to see.

I must admit I went into this movie rather blind, I did not realize it was a romance movie. I hate romance movies but there was something amazing about this movie. It did not make me feel like I was watching a romance but rather one man's struggle to cope with a disease that is slowly shutting your body down, yet your brain remains active and amazingly bright. It is a much watch movie, if you hate romance movies this is one of the only "romance" movies I would recommend watching.

I purchased this movie because my sister passed away from ALS in 2010 at the age of 41.  It took me a few weeks to watch it after purchasing it, as I was sure it would be bring back memories of my sister and her battle with the disease.  Eddie Redmayne did an amazing job capturing how the illness affects the body.  Spoiler alert!  I was a little shocked that HE left his wife who had cared for him for some many years.  My sister's husband left her a year and half into the illness and remarried shortly after their divorce.  He took their son with him too.  My sister lasted 3 1/2 more years.  Dealing with a terminal illness is bad enough, but having to go through the heartache of losing a husband and child was unimaginable. Thankfully, my mother stepped up to become her primary caregiver.  My mother and sister went through so much those last couple years.  My mother is the best mom ever.  And my sister was a strong person.  I miss her.  :(

Thoroughly enjoyed the movie about Stephen Hawking.  Eddie Redmayne's acting was excellent.  Felicity Jones does an amazing job as Hawking's first wife, Jane.  This rendition focuses more on the relationship between he and Jane; the point of view is hers (it is based on the book by Jane Hawking, so this was expected). The tender, loving relationship between Jane and Stephen was brought to life through emotional scenes that exposed some of their incredible challenges as a young married couple. An educated person herself, Jane remained focused and unrelenting in her care and support for her genius husband. This biopic doesn't gloss over the fact that they divorced and remarried their assistants; it was not represented salaciously, but part of the narrative. It is obvious their relationship remained loving and intact despite the hardships and eventual separation.  If you are interested in another excellent rendition, watch BBC's 2004 "Hawking" starring Benedict Cumberbatch that focuses more on Hawking's early years and some of his scientific work during university years is explored more.

My first introduction to Stephen Hawking was after graduating high school when I first read his "Theory of Everything". If they would have had subtitles for Hawkings character, who got more incomprehensible as the movie progressed, I might have given this 4 or 5 stars. It is a really well done movie. I just got annoyed trying to understand that character toward the end...

The human interest story is built from powerful ingredients, but I felt like it loses its way--unless the intention was to show an empty and unsatisfying resolution. I came away thinking the poignancy of Hawking's struggles with ALS had been well addressed, and that the film had done a great job showing how that heavy burden shaped his wife's life experience as well. But then it didn't do anything profound or satisfying with that theme. There was a beautiful moment when Hawking and his ex-wife are admiring the children they had together, and a sort-of dream sequence where Hawking gets out of his chair and conveys something (what, I don't know, and I'm not sure the filmmakers did, either). But there was no denoument--just a kind of sad loss of hope and a bittersweet memory of past tenderness. Not a bad movie, and well acted--but not worth all the effusive praise I'm seeing, either.

"The Theory of Everything" is beautifully written and directed. This movie is based on a true story, obviously. It's about the incredible mind of theorist, Stephen Hawking and his descent/struggle with ALS. Eddie Redmayne plays Hawking. Wow. What a performance. Of course Redmayne won an Oscar for this lovely film. I've seen him in other films ("My Week with Marilyn" and "Hick") and thought - this guy has got the goods! He's a tremendous talent. His face is so expressive and he's such a dedicated and fearless actor. And let's not forget about the equally talented (and the gorgeous), Felicity Jones. Jones is breathtaking to watch as Jane, Hawkin's strong-as-nails wife. I'm so thrilled Jones is finally getting the recognition she so rightfully deserves. Her performance is both sensitive and emotionally strong. Redmayne and Jones's chemistry is electric and palpable. My only gripe is the film is a bit slow and tends to drag but overall, I found "The Theory of Everything" a delight to watch. It moved me to tears. Stunning film and beautifully cinematography. Give this drama a viewing or two. Enjoy!
One of last year's most inspiring, genuine films that is fuelled by stellar acting from Redmayne & Jones. Truly masterful movie making.

Read the New York Times review, which I read only after watching the movie.  Eddie Redmayne did a great job, but the audience has absolutely no idea what Hawking actually accomplished.  We're just supposed to know he is "pretty smart."  I didn't expect a dissertation, but they could have, just once, explained what he did, or HOW he managed to develop his theories--they never show him actually working.  Maybe he worked with a grad student who wrote on a chalkboard?  Maybe he was able to do all the proofs in his head?  Whatever, I left the movie totally confused.  As did my husband, a physicist!

First, anyone who has compared Redmayne to Lewis, you are insane, and I cannot address you.  Second, this is typical melodramatic linear nonsense that Hollywood loves to throw an Oscar at.  Consider "King's Speech" or that crap movie with Russell Crowe that Ron Howard directed about the guy who pioneered game theory.  It's bad, and it's been done before.  And...they collapse decades into a few hours which means most of the film is a montage.  Then you have Redmayne.  I have never wanted to punch an actor or anyone in my whole life.  Full disclosure, I watched this on a plane with the sound off.  But, and I mean BUT, it made the flight longer.  I'd give it at least two stars because some good people worked on this giant turd.  The costume people, the wardrobe the makeup, etc. everyone who doesn't get credit.  Out of respect for those people working for a living I give it one star.  How Keaton was passed over for this is only testament that he has offended the right people over the years.  And Hawking...he's not a hero.  Really not a hero.  He's smart.  He got a disease and that sucks.  But so do millions of other people who have contributed as much to modern physics as he.  Nothing.  He's bright, but he's no Newton.  Much less an Einstein.  And yes, he cheated on the woman in the movie.

This film has flaws ... it tries to cover an immense amount of time (something Steven Hawking has studied his entire life) into a very "brief" film.  The result seems choppy.  You don't get enough feeling of the terribly rigorous family life; the children are not in the film very much and it seems as if they must be living somewhere else perhaps.  The principle characters simply do not age appropriately, especially Mrs. Hawking who looks around 25 through most of the film, which for someone managing such an enormous burden would be impossible.

That said, the acting was so impeccable, so brilliant, that it overcame the flaws for me.  Eddie Redmayne and Felicity Jones masterfully conveyed both the enormity of the catastrophe that befell Mr. Hawking and the brave young woman, Jane, who would become his wife, as well as the incredible mutual LOVE that allowed Steven Hawking to live, to persist in his intellectual quest for a unifying theory, becoming world renowned as a physicist and beloved as a person of tremendous personal endurance and good will.

Small wonder Eddie Redmayne won the Oscar for essentially "becoming" Stephen Hawking. The glow of kindness, compassion and humor radiating from his face reduced me to tears.  Felicity Jones certainly deserved her nomination for Best Actress in a Leading Role.

This film is full of flaws only in not being able to encompass a lifetime in a couple of hours, but a total success in letting us understand and rejoice in the story of this man's extraordinary personal life.
