I was beyond stunned by the beauty of THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING. Everything about this film is stellar-especially the amazing  cast . I held back for a long time in seeing this film thinking I wasn't interested in a film about a science genius. THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING is actually the story of two people in love and defying amazing odds. Based on Jane Hawking's book about her life with Stephen Hawking, THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING bombards us with the stark reality of a love story in crisis. She was there with him from the beginning.
A shy young lady named Jane (the gorgeous Felicity Jones) falls in love with science geek Stephen Hawking. The film is slow moving at first and seemingly uninspired. It's a "we've seen it before"  love story between a beautiful lady and a nerdy geek.  But, suddenly, the story shifts and we are riveted to the end.  Hawking is diagnosed with ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease). Doctors give him two years to live.
Here is where the story really begins as Jane eagerly embraces a chance to spend those two years with Hawking and be by his side. But through an amazing miracle and twist, Hawking lives decades beyond his promised two years. A truly remarkable and bittersweet story emerges as Jane becomes the eternal caregiver to Hawking as well as mother to their children. Here is a rarely explored side to the Stephen Hawking story and it makes for a fascinating film. The caregiver's story is often neglected and finally we see a loving and courageous woman buckling to the stress.

Eddie Redmayne does an incredibly realistic portrayal of Hawking as his body deteriorates. Redmayne puts his soul and body into the role. This was a physically challenging role and Redmayne  portrays Hawking with sensitivity and realism.
This is a beautiful period piece that is stunning to look at. THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING is inspiring, heartbreaking and bittersweet but we see love overcomes all adversity...but even love has its limits in the end.

Wow! I've admired Stephen Hawking for a very long time. The guy's unstoppable. He doesn't quit in the face of survival odds. And in this film Eddie Redmayne was Stephen Hawking - no doubt about it.  I rented and watched this film on Easter Sunday, April 5, 2015. That morning I had chatted with a friend about atheism and he told me it cleared his head. I thought this curious and yet in this film, that's nearly exactly how Hawking explains his atheism and focus in relation to physics. I prefer the magic of belief - The Miracles - The Resurrection. I live in Southeastern Pennsylvania where there's a shrine to the Catholic Saint, Padre Pio, who had healing gifts. Stephen Hawking persistently searches for a Theory of Everything, a Holy Grail of unification. Living in survival mode with severe challenges of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS-Lou Gehrig's Disease), Hawking's greatest achievement was in the gift of friends and family. In an interview with "Parade Magazine" of Sunday, September 12, 2010, when asked "If people could take just one lesson from your work or from your life, what would you want it to be?' Hawking's reply was "Do your best." This says it all.

The problem with this movie is that it downplays Stephen Hawkings' actual accomplishments and makes his love life seem much more important. Don't get me wrong, I'm sure he needed all the love and support he could get, and in order to make a blockbuster you have to beef up the drama, but what about those of us who watched this movie because our love for science? Besides the most rudimentary explanation of quantum v. General relativity physics, there is virtually nothing scientifically interesting to be had in this movie. I didn't expect a discovery channel special, but the scientific aspect was so neglected that you could swap out the "ailed physics genius" story line for just about any other "ailed genius" story and get almost the same exact movie. Again, it's not like I expected a course in physics, but it would have been nice for this movie to take advantage of its subject and try to teach something besides that tired old "love prevails" stuff we get out of almost every movie ever. It would have been interesting to see him struggling with developing his theory and/or getting other scientists to back him. There are a few brief instances of this, but they are so detached from actual content that they just add to the sense of a shell-like drama - beautiful outside but devoid of any inner substance. It's like the studio took a story that was interesting on all levels and sucked out everything except a love story. Even his disease loses weight as the film goes on, to the point that it makes it seem as him writing a 200+ page book was easy. Do you know how long that must have taken him? This movie made it seem like a breeze. And I can't believe that yet again, an actor that played a sick person won the academy award. It's especially annoying in this case because (no offense, just being real) as the movie goes on, the actor does less and less real acting and the makeup team becomes more and more responsible for the convincing performance. Still, it is well acted on all parts, and it has some very interesting cinematography as well as great music, but the story is bare bones and devoid of substance. If you thought the subject matter would provide an interesting twist on a typical dramatic setup, think again. It didn't. But if you want A Walk to Remember where Mandy Moore doesn't die but just so happens to be a genius, then this is your movie.

All that to say - eh....it was a good movie, interesting, portrayed our human frailties & flaws...gave insight to his life, some great acting  by both actors and all of the supporting actors, but it just didn't make our list of films we would want to own or have in our library. Every bit of this film is heart breaking, but at the same time it is inspiring to see that even though everything has gone wrong for a brilliant mind. I can't even explain how beyond disappointed I was with this film.  It came out in theaters when my baby was born, and my husband and I really wanted to go see it in the theater.  The trailers looked so good.  LOOKED is the right word.  While the lighting was really beautiful and the actors charming, I didn't get the sense of any struggle in their marriage.  I didn't know anything about this marriage and was not surprised it didn't work out, but there was no depiction of what it must have been like for them to be married.  You just saw her doing various house chores and holding new babies.  I imagine she must have been incredibly overwhelmed, but you didn't really see that.  And then in one scene, it just ended.  Very anti-climactic.
I think the biggest problem with this movie was that it didn't really focus on one thing.  I wish they had focused on either his work, their marriage, or his condition.

Do you remember early 2002, when a certain generic biopic won the Oscar over the mega-popular one-two punch of Moulin Rouge! and The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring?  It was inevitable, we all saw it coming (or we should have) and yet the months that followed brought scorn and resentment over the Oscar winner, scorn and resentment that are still heaped upon its back.  You see, I liked A Beautiful Mind.  I still do.  Its a simple made film that follows some basic tropes that all biopics tend to fall into, and yet it was engaging and enjoyable and littered with interesting and beautiful performances.  Still, its a film that can be taken for granted and dismissed as by the books and, as I noted above, generic.

I never truly realized how good of a movie A Beautiful Mind was until I sat down to watch The Theory of Everything.

It had the comparisons running alongside it all year, many calling this 2014s A Beautiful Mind, and it was clear why, for both films were essentially stories about brilliant men saddled with a disability (one mental, the other physical) who were saved by the love of a woman.  The difference is that A Beautiful Mind actually has something to say.  While The Theory of Everything is quite beautiful to look at and has a stunning (albeit obvious and at times distracting) score, but it also doesnt tell us anything about the man in question, throws out jargon no one is going to pay attention to, and features two performances that are (while technically accurate and, at least for one, physically outstanding) quite boring and empty.

If I knew nothing about Stephen Hawking before watching this, Id know nothing more now, other than the fact that he got sick, fathered kids and didn't believe in God (or did he?).

The Theory of Everything seems pretty content with putting flashy filters all over every scene and regurgitating depictions of grief through showy edits (that call into question just how involved Redmaynes transformation really was) but never really settles down to tell us the story of this man, what hes thinking, who he isinsideapart from his crippling disability.  I understand that explaining to us Hawkings lifework would have been hard, and it would have gone over many heads, but the point of a biopic isn't really to explain a profession but an individual, and I feel as though Hawking, the man, is never cracked open for us.  We know nothing about him outside of the fact that hes smart and awkward.  We learn a great deal more about his wife, Jane, but sadly Felicity Jones is so dreadfully dull in her delivery that she may as well have not even existed.

At least when A Beautiful Mind ended (which, by the way, is nowhere near as generic as its accused of being) I felt like I knew this man and I knew his wife and I felt their love and their support and I felt his pain and I felt his growth.  When The Theory of Everything ended I felt nothing but the urge to eject the DVD.

But its pretty, you know, visually.

As far as Redmayne and his Oscar win are concerned, I get it.  I mean, from a physical aspect he really goes all out there and commands every movement, every physical deteriorating moment.  Like I said, some of the flashy edits call into question how far he went or if his performance was sliced, diced and spliced to create something that looked more incredible than it was; but regardless, he is convincing as a man suffering from ALS.  What hes not convincing as is as a man.  There is nothing behind those eyes, no real character to explore.  Its all surface, nothing genuine here.  Charlie Cox is the only person who really shines here.  Felicity Jones has the most fleshed out character but, like, she does nothing with it.

I wanted to like this.  I mean, it was getting such a thrashing from so many people who were mad that Michael Keaton lost the Oscar, and so I was hoping that it was just vitiral and nothing really warranted.  Yeah, this movie is just empty and that bleeds into every aspect of the film.  Even the cinematography is overtly showy, pretty with no real substance, and the score, which is genuinely beautiful, is used to death in a way that makes it feel cheap; like it has nothing to say.

Thats the problem here; this film has nothing to say.

He wasn't speaking well, so it would have been difficult to dictate; he couldn't write, so how did he do it?  It happened, so How?  That kind of bothered me.  Otherwise, it met all our expectations for a lovely movie..

I have been following Stephen Hawking's career for many years and this movie goes beyond anything I ever expected in a depiction of Hawking's life.  I can fully understand why Eddie Redmayne won the Best Actor Oscar - his performance was unbelievable.  His makeup artist nailed his appearance as Hawking both as a young man and as a world-renowned physicist in his later years.  I could not believe Redmayne could contort his body the way he did when portraying Hawking in a wheel chair.  It is my understanding that the real Hawking was so impressed by what he saw in the production footage that he permitted the producers to use the actual computer voice that he speaks with all the time.  Even in the midst of the physical incapacitation of Lou Gehrig's Disease, Hawking is portrayed as self-assured, mentally acute and still more than willing to "explore new frontiers [with apologies to Star Trek]" in science.  Hawking fan or not, I recommend this movie to all who admire the refusal of the human spirit to give in to physical adversity while at the same time letting the mind soar.  Hawking's body may be imprisoned in a wheel chair, but there are no fetters, shackles or obstacles that will shutter his brilliant mind.

I thoroughly enjoyed watching "The Theory or Everything" though it wasn't the story I was expecting. I anticipated learning more about Hawking's disease and his brilliant theories, but those were really just subplots to the greater plot which was his relationship with Jane and his family and colleagues. You already know by now that Eddy Redmayne's acting was superb. His physical mastery of the role was remarkable, and in many scenes, after Hawking had lost his ability to talk, Redmayne communicated simply with limited facial expressions. The scene when he and Jane decide that their marriage is over, even with very few words spoken, is heartbreaking.

It was interesting to know more about Hawking's personal life. I had no idea that he had fathered 3 children. The ending felt rather truncated and rushed though. We don't get to know that his marriage to Elaine lasted just 6 years; In fact after he announced that he was leaving Jane, we never saw Elaine again at all. The movie does ring true, however, and received the admiration and endorsement of Hawking who felt that Redmayne had captured him very well.

THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING has everything you'd expect from the typical Hollywood biopic, and as such is rather predictable. Not only that, but its subject is still alive (and very famous) which robs it of a lot of dramatic tension. Still, Eddie Redmayne gives an extraordinary, transformative performance as Stephen Hawking, as does Felicity Jones as his long-suffering first wife Jane. The story starts with Hawking's years at Cambridge and up through the publication of "A Brief History of Time." Instead of focusing on the accomplishments, the film is really about the relationship between him and his first wife, as the book is based on her memoir. The romance kind of comes out of nowhere, but after spending two hours with them you really begin to feel for them, especially Jane, who ended up having to put in overtime as her husband's caregiver (until help was brought in). The scenes which show the gradual progress of Hawking's condition (Motor Neuron Disease/ALS) were quite moving as well, but only in the most general sense. It also "helped" that the score hinted at just the right moments when you were supposed to be emotionally affected. So, while the film is sure to stir up emotion and possibly provoke tears at certain points, nothing the film does with those moments is that special in and of itself. What really makes this film worth seeing is for Eddie Redmayne's performance, which deservedly won him the Best Actor Oscar this year. Of course, the rest of the cast, which includes Emily Watson, Charlie Cox and David Thewlis, does outstanding work as well. Overall, it's not particularly groundbreaking in terms of the biopic and romance formula, or in its execution, but Eddie Redmayne takes it to another level with his portrayal of one of the world's greatest living minds.

This is not a romance, although romance is a force in this biography. The story has many layers and offers the philosophical a significant number of concepts to ponder for example: are relationships for a lifetime or for a purpose, what S.H. had chosen end-of-life procedures when he was diagnosed, will he discover the one mathematical equation to explain time and what impact will that have on mankind, what did he mean in saying "as long as we are alive there is hope, do we witness a scientist-searcher changing over time to a person of wonder who is considering the possibility of a Creator and more.. For the less philosophical, it amazing on many levels, such as why is this individual able to continue living and even working when this terrible disease takes lives within months and/or short number of years after diagnosis, how does he maintain his sense of humor, how did his wife maintain her commitment to him over time, why did he let her..... don't want to ruin the movie for you all....

This is a fine film.  Hawkings science is noted in the course of the story and the highlights are briefly described, but the film principally concerns his relationship with his first wife, Jane.  Based on her memoir, it effectively communicates both their love and the difficulty of their situation, particularly after the arrival of their third child.

As most will know, Jane was helped with Stephens care by a man named Jonathan Jones, her choir director and sons piano teacher.  When they develop feelings for one another they separate, in fairness to Stephen.  When Stephen develops feelings for his new nurse and travels with her to the U.S., Jane and Jonathans relationship is greenlighted.  The film leaves Stephens future with the nurse vague (they married and then later divorced), Stephen and Jane remaining lifelong friends.

This is the sum and substance of the film.  The performances are consistently excellent, the atmospherics warm and foreboding, as necessary.  The film is shot with a very bluish palette.  Whole scenes seem to consist of blue grass, blue trees and blue buildings.

The film is perhaps 20-30 minutes longer than it needs to be.  Caveat emptor with regard to Hawkings science.  The film gives it short shrift; this is a love story and a representation of the effects of SHs disease, not a complete biography.

I learned a great deal about Stephen Hawkings. I did not know he had ALS and was diagnosed in his early 20s. I didn't know they only gave him a few months to live and now he is 73. I did not know he was married, had a family and even has grandchildren. I looked him up online to find out more about him. My son was diagnosed with a disease at 28 and lost his ability to walk among other things. His life is also said to be shortened. He is on a quest to heal himself or find a healer. The movie gave me hope and courage..I spoke of it with my son also. All the above make this a great and memorable movie.

If you are looking for a biopic about why Stephen Hawking is a physics genius, this isn't it. The Theory of Everything is more about his marriage. I don't think you have to know squat about physics or Stephen Hawkings to appreciate a story about how a bright young woman meets an awkward young man and commits to him even after she finds out that he has a degenerative disease that will take his ability to move before it takes his life in two years or less. Is it true? I hear that it's not and actually it feels VERY white washed because no one is THAT good. No marriage is that trouble-free- especially with the stressors that those two had. But is that the point of the movie? I don't think so. But, does it leave you with the feeling inspired and good all over? Yes, it did for me.

On a side note, I LOVE that Eddie Redmayne is getting the attention from Hollywood that he deserves. He's a fine actor. I am glad he's getting the roles that prove it. Although Harry Lloyd didn't have a huge part, it was fabulous seeing him too. Here's the the second British invasion. I hope Hollywood is taking note and will continue hiring talent over pretty fluff.

As a faith believer my review is influenced by who I am. Though I was very impressed with the love story and the devotion of Wilde to her husband in this impossible situation for any family and how they together through their love for each other overcame insurmountable odds it always amazes me how much credibility is given to what is essentially a guess and an opinion proposed by a scientist which is no better than the doctrines of faith proposed by religion.
There is no conclusive proof by either as to how life began. Both offer what they consider the substance of their arguments but without the full scientific process which is supposed to establish an indisputable conclusion it is not a fact and yet global warming, the theory of evolution and any number of scientific opinions are applied by our society from scientists (the high priest of secular society) as if they are proven facts when they are not.
A large number of scientific theories on life, the existence of the cosmos or the human health have been shown to be wrong and reassessed after many years of our society living by those theories until someone one days examines their claims and finds them unsubstantiated.
So though I found the story inspiring, interesting and thought provoking on one level on another it is just another effort from the antagonists of faith to undermine faith and empower themselves on the gullibility of most people, especially people who are looking for just another excuse to attack religion so that they can justify themselves in living outside of the bounds and responsibilities of ethical and moral behavior.

That's saying something, but there was nothing else about it that I really liked.  It took us through too much of what was going on with him personally.  I would have preferred they illustrated why he thought Time was such an interesting subject, what was going on in the world that lead him there, what was his home and family like... It was a well made movie, but I couldn't get past Hawkins' atheism. Either the universe is eternal, it created itself, or it was created. Both The big Bang and the 2nd Law of Thermodynamics rule out a eternal universe. The Law of Cause and Effect rules out the universe creating itself. That only leaves it was created by a creator. But a cosmologist cannot allow for a creator even though that's where science and common sense actually lead. But of course I knew all this going in.

Elegant and bittersweet.  Eddie Redmayne was a good choice for best actor (how did he contort his fingers, or did the filmmakers do it?) and I was pleased to see Jane Hawking's story adapted for a larger audience.  All in all, I think the film is one of the stronger historical adaptations, mixing everyday meaning and drama with an unusual affliction and a monumental life.  No film can ever be completely true-to-life, but I thought there was respect here for both the subject and the viewers.  Hopefully, interested viewers will consider reading /Traveling to Infinity/, the novel by Jane on which the film is based, and learing more about the life and times of her and Stephen.

The performance of Eddie Redmayne was brilliant - if you watch for no other reason, watch to see him perform. Felicity Jones was incredible too. The story of Stephen Hawking fascinates me. I started to read "A Brief History of Time" years ago and my head started to hurt - our universe is so old, so big, and we as human being so small, so insignificant, such little blips in the ocean of time and space. It was hard to keep going but after watching this movie, I feel inspired to read it again - or attempt to do so at any rate.

My favorite scenes of the movie are below:
1. When he is first diagnosed with his disease and he wants to know if the brain gets affected too - his relief that the brain remains intact and functional.
2. When his bride confides in Stephen's father that she may seem weak but she is a strong woman and she loves Stephen and wants to be with him. no matter how long they may have.
3. When he shows up for his PhD certification and hears the team of professors comment on his work.
4. When he is looking at his three grown children and looks over to his wife, saying, "Look at what we created together." The miracle of parenthood surpassing even his own work in that moment.

The movie is one of the best I have seen - it touches you on so many levels and made me appreciate - on a whole new level - my ability to function normally and have full use of all my body parts and to feel more compassion towards those who suffer from terrible diseases such as Lou Gherig's. And it made me appreciate the work and dedication of Stephen Hawking to science and advancement of human knowledge so much more. Watch it and be awe-inspired!

A fascinating movie, both for the personal story and for the glimpses into the lives of geniuses.  Everything is quite understated, making everything quite beautiful.  Had to watch twice.  The answer to the last question in the last scene of the film was especially moving:  the acknowledgement that human beings and human nature are limited, and because this is so, human nature wants something without limits.  This is apparently what S. Hawking showed scientifically - how the universe has no boundaries, has no limits.  As I learned in my catechetical studies when a young person, and as J. Hawking apparently believed, God is everywhere present, is all knowing, and is all powerful - in other words has no boundaries or limits.
So how or why need there be controversy?  As Robert Frost says:  "Having ideas that are neither pro nor con is the happy thing.  Get up there high enough and the differences that make controversy become only the two legs of a body the weight of which is on one in one period, on the other in the next."  In God's house are "many mansions":  some are merely scientific, some are merely religious, but with the grace of art and imagination, some participate in an interchange of both.

This is a FANTASTIC movie. We bought it over the weekend, and watched it on the same day. Stellar performances by both. Beautifully written, nicely paced. Incredibly powerful story of perseverance, faith and love. Surprised it didn't win more awards. Very deserving of all the accolades it has got so far and continues to get.

Eddie Redmayne won a well-deserved Oscar for his performance, which is well worth seeing, but the rest of this film was a letdown for me. No doubt out of respect for avoiding lawsuits from the still living subjects, the film is sanitized to an extreme. For example, there is no attempt to show the sort of day-to-day drudgery his wife must have experienced. After all, the man could not properly attend to himself in the bathroom, brush his teeth, or do any of the dozens of small day to day activities we take for granted. Yet the only visual evidence we are given for his wife's growing disenchantment is her difficulty in completing her thesis on Iberian poetry, because Hawking is in the next room using his electric wheelchair to horse around with the children. The man she eventually cheats with is presented as an almost cartoonish paragon of goodness and virtue, while the caretaker Hawking cheats with is portrayed as some sort of snake in the garden. The whole infidelity thing unfolds like a slow motion train wreck: you can see it coming, but it takes a while for the movie to get where you've been for the past hour.
The filmmaker's use of color is distracting, bathing some scenes in warm orange light as if the actors were under the heat lamp at McDonalds, while other scenes are done in a washed out blue. For a situation that seems so fraught with emotion, this is a very tepid drama. No one is to blame you see, and we're all veddy English.

Side note: Hawkings theory is a popular theory about the beginning of the universe, but not generally accepted by contemporary cosmology. See Vilenkin: "But in 2003, a team including Vilenkin and Guth considered what eternal inflation would mean for the Hubble constant, which describes mathematically the expansion of the universe. They found that the equations didn't work (Physical Review Letters, DOI: 10.1103/physrevlett. 90.151301). You cant construct a space-time with this property, says Vilenkin. It turns out that the constant has a lower limit that prevents inflation in both time directions. It cant possibly be eternal in the past, says Vilenkin. There must be some kind of boundary.

How can you not respect Stephen Hawking?  How can you not appreciate Eddie Redmayne's compassionate portrayal of him?  But Jane and Stephen are divorced, after all, much as this film tries to downplay the split.  Hollywood has a history of whitewashing all our cultural heroes.  That's not exactly a bad thing.  Society needs its icons.  Still...I'm not sure it was necessary to candy-coat this couple's relationship.  They were fighting an incredible battle together and facing extreme challenges.  Clearly neither one of them has any interest in denigrating the other.  That's nice, but the hasn't truth become muddled in their discretion?  What are we to take away from it all?  My question then becomes why bother telling the 'intimate' story at all?  Left me wondering.

You'd pretty much have to be living in a cave to not know about Stephan Hawking and the remarkable impact he's made on physics, while having done so under the most extreme of afflictions. Here is a great chance to examine him in clearer detail.

Here's the scoop. Taken from Hawking's ex-wife's book, this movie takes the viewer through Stephen's life just prior to meeting her, the onset of his A.L.S. and how they dealt with it as they both carve out their careers.

Everything great you might have heard about this film is absolutely true. Movies simply do not get much better than this. Start with a great script by screenwriter and book author Anthony McCarten. Supplement that with outstanding performances by the likes of Eddie Redmayne, Felicity Jones and a host of other veterans. Then add the adroit directing by James Marsh and everything comes together in a glorious whole. This is a great film. Though it will pull on your emotions it doesn't come from cheap manipulation of the audience. It comes from circumstance itself. Redmayne doesn't solicit 'poor me. poor me' from the audience (though there is some of that at the onslaught of the illness). He spends much of the time trying to work around it. He manages to maintain a certain amount of charm and humor. It IS more of a triumph than anything. Yes. Things are tough but I felt great when it was over. This is not a downer flick.

See it. It is well worth your time and money.

Okay, so Birdman won best picture. If I were voting though I would have chosen either this movie or Whiplash. I knew about Steven Hawking's life but not intimately. After watching Eddie Redmayne portray Hawking though, I feel differently. I cannot imagine how anyone could not be profoundly moved by this film. It is simply excellent from beginning to end. Although Redmayne won the best actor Oscar, every character in this film is excellent. Beautifully directed and once again proves that factual stories are typically more interesting than fiction.

Thought the acting was amazing for both Felicity Jones and Eddie Redmayne.  The story is great and of course quite a tear jerker.  Unfortunately, the story tells almost nothing about the physics behind why Hawking is such an amazing and famous scientist.  It's like they thought the science would be too hard for audiences. Also, this movie perpetuates the myth that Stephen Hawking is a gentle, benevolent man...when in fact he is (apparently) difficult, obstinate, and a bit of a narcissistic jerk.  Oh well...this movie perpetuates the myth. I liked the movie, but not sure I would recommend it.

Steven Hawking is certainly a one-in-a-million person, but this story isn't that interesting.  It focuses on his two main relationships (with lots of pretty views of Oxford); so it's really a romance movie.  There is not very much on how he dealt with his progressive disease from a psychological point of view and virtually nothing about his theoretical work or how he was able to continue to pursue it despite the difficulties.

Very much a "hollywood" take on things, pretty and glossy but somehow neutered.  It was a surprise, since the director's documentary "Man on Wire" was absolutely riveting.
Dialogue was hard to understand at times, especially the first 5-10 minutes.  The background music and sound was too loud.

I found this film to be the least likely film to be nominated for the academy award. Too much is unexplained. Example 1: While at Cambridge in 1963 Hawking is diagnosed with ALS and given two years to live. The film gives no explanation how he has survived so long. Example 2: The theory of everything could have been explained better so that the average viewer could have been better drawn into the mind of Hawking. I would have loved to see a short FX scene demonstrating the birth of our Solar System from a Black Hole, with narration by Hawking would have helped immensely.  Example 3: I say; Hawking saw that his wife needed more than he could possibly give her and decided to make the break with his wife by pretending to be in love with his caregiver. My wife says: Stephen Hawking is a jerk. After all his wife did for him, he decided to leave her for someone else. Perhaps the book is more clear on these questions but the movie should have been... My wife came away from this film caring less about Stephen Hawking than before... and I have to agree.

I can give you my theory of what this film is about: The disease Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), aka; Lou Gehrig's Disease and the hardship it causes the people who have it and the loved one's around them. This film offers little else in the way of substance and certainly could have been told without Stephen and Jane Hawking. It is neither a Historical piece, a scientific exploration or, as the film has many inaccuracies can't even be labeled a proper biography.

As far as Academy Awards go, Redmayne did a wonderful job impersonating Hawking, but should simple impersonation really translate to Best Performance of the year by an actor?
I thought Michael Keaton (Birdman) was robbed. Also Benedict Cumberbatch (The Imitation Game) who's performance of that other Cambridge genius Alan Turing was mesmerizing.
So moving! I loved every minute of this movie!!

I gave this 3 stars mainly because of the outstanding acting done by the lead actor, the lead actress was passable also.  The rest, eh?  My problem and the reason it is just 3 stars is I took 4 away before added two for the acting.  This was a plain to see Oscar bait movie that didn't know what it wanted to be except try to win Oscars.  Thank goodness the Academy seen through that and only gave it the best actor oscar.  Yes, Stephen Hawking is a compelling person and his story would be great movie to see but this was not the one.  It doesn't know what angle the movie wants to protray the story, is it a heartache story of a severely physically disabled husband who wants his wife to be happy and the loving wife who secretly suffers from not having a fully functioning husband, or is it a brilliant man and his theories no matter the limitations caused by disease with his wife who supports him beyond most would.  It tries to be both and fails miserably.

Movie was well done, overall. Nice transformations of by the actors of the aging characters. Since the movie was based on a book written by Hawking's ex-wife, I don't know how he feels about it. But the presentation of the difficulties of dealing w/ this situation seemed pretty evenhanded. Would recommend it to anyone familiar w/ some of Hawking's books/ideas.

One of the best movies I've seen in years.  The acting is superb and the story does a great job of integrating Hocking's personal life with his revolutionary contributions to theoretical physics.  Fascinating narrative of a genius who is a personable, attractive person while laboring in the most abstract levels of science and experiencing the progressive physical limitations of ALS.  A remarkable and inspiring story told directly by this well scripted and well acted film.  Not to be missed!

Great movie! It's not just about Science. It's about human perserverance, triumph against all odds, and positive attitudes on life.  The main actor that portraying Professor Stephen Hawkings deserve the Academy Awards!!! He did a phenomenal job!  He was so good that we almost forgot that he was an actor portraying a character and not Stephen himself. We, a bunch of us, highly recommended this movie.  Enjoy!

Hawking is portrayed by Eddie Redmayne, an actor who's deserved his chance to shine for a long time now. His performance is nothing short of beauty, especially considering the movie was filmed out of sequence. His ability to show the many stages of Hawking's illness is remarkably impressive. Felicity Jones' performance as Hawking's wife Jane is equally impressive as we watch her struggle to maintain her husband's condition.

Unfortunately, the rest of the film is not so adept. The film plays out like the very mathematical equations in which its subject envelopes himself. It almost feels like a TV movie in its formulaic sympathy. That's not to say it isn't a tragic story, but its telling did little for me.

For the first two-thirds or so, the film doesn't seem to know what it wants to be: A touching story of a seemingly doomed affair, or a bold statement on Hawking's theories. Ultimately it succeeds at neither, amounting to a light, safe, almost entirely forgettable romantic drama. Even the score, which has been winning countless awards this season, I found indistinguishable from any number of films of the same ilk.

I really hate the term "Oscar Bait," but if a movie were to define it, this would be the one. Its only salvation is the performances of its leads, who seem to be the only ones giving the film any heart.
Best movie ever a see. Well deserved oscar!

He was fabulous...in what had to have been a most difficult part to play!!  Well, he did it!  I also have to say what a remarkable man Dr. Hawking must be.  It appears he has gone through a lot of this keeping his sense of humor in tact.  And, that he is still alive shows me (ironically) that God definitely had a purpose for this man.  He certainly did not let "life" stop him.  I am still shaking my head in amazement at what Hawking has done with his life.  I'm now reading his first wife's book.  She was, I have to say also, an amazing woman.  Raising three children and attending to his every need...she has earned that star in heaven.  Still puzzled why he wanted to marry Elaine - and now I read that she (allegedly) treated him very badly...she was after money and fame, that's all.

Stephen Hawking is known for his brilliant mind and his incredible persistence in the face of adversity. This film provides a picture of the person inside of the accolades. A fine cast brings the well nuanced character and his family to light.

The version with Benedict Cumberbatch is much better than this "remake." The director used the interview with Hawking to sensationalize the movie, and it turned out to be nothing more than a let down.

When I first contemplated watching this movie, I thought to myself, "But how can it be a romance when we already know they get divorced later in life?"

But I was intrigued...and I watched it...and I must say despite the fact that Jane and Stephen get divorced later, that this is a story about love. There are many different kinds of love and you can love someone one way and later find you love them another way. You don't stop loving them; your love just changes. I think this movie should have been called The Evolution of Love. I do.

The movie starts in 1962(3?) Cambridge and we meet a young student Stephen who is working on his PhD and Jane who is majoring in some kind of poetry. I saw something special in Jane right away. This is a girl/woman is one tough cookie. The girl Jane does not take no for an answer. When she finds out her boyfriend has only two years to live, when Stephen's own family warns her she should walk away now, she sticks to her guns. She's going to marry the man she loves and enjoy what times she has with him.

Woman Jane is amazing. She has to juggle small children as well as an invalid Stephen, so it's like having a grown kid on top of the little kids. I don't mean this in an insulting way, but she has to dress him and feed him and all that, and it's obvious she has her hands full and for many years her husband refused to hire outside help.

And you can tell at times that she's unhappy but she's hanging in there. And she's faced with some difficult choices. And she never breaks down.

She does not walk away until Stephen basically tells her to. And then finally she's permitted to find her own happiness.

And yet she still loved him; her love just evolved into a different type.

There are parts of the movie dedicated to Stephen's theories. I didn't understand much of it. It confused me, to be honest. If you are proving your theory from a few years ago wrong now...what makes this theory right? And why are theories so applauded when they're constantly proved wrong? It's all very confusing to me. Thankfully the movie didn't expand on that stuff too much. I may have blown a brain fuse.

But I really enjoyed this movie, the settings, the acting...omg, the acting was something. I applaud them all, especially the actor who played Stephen. And I walk away from the sofa now with a new thought planted in my head...as long as there is life, there is hope.

I bought this movie expecting a romance or a dramatic biography about the famous physicist, but I think Jane's strength stole the show.

The Theory of Everything isn't everything is should have been. This film has production values like a TV Movie. The universal acclaim makes me wonder if film reviewers get paid to praise films. Eddie Redmayne delivers a good performance. However, he is not Daniel Day Lewis in My Left Foot (he deserved his Oscar in 1990). Eddie didn't completely transform himself they way Steve Carell did in "Foxcatcher". After "Savage Grace" in 2007 Eddie Redmayne needed to have his SAG card revoked. The script if full of holes and it doesn't cover the fact that Hawking dumped his wife and mother of his children for his nurse after like 30 years of marriage and 3 kids. Clearly everyone in Hollywood wants to keep the big UK tax incentive credit for film makers going so honoring Eddie with Best Actor was a way to recognize that special relationship. That is the only possible explanation for his winning Best Actor.

We wanted to see this after watching the Oscars, because there were so many excellent candidates for Best Actor.  Now that we've seen it, we completely understand why Eddie Redmayne won.  His characterization of Stephen Hawking was outstanding, both physically and dramatically.  My only complaint is that for the first 15 minutes, we could hardly understand a word; between the accents and the sound recording and editing, it was very frustrating.  After that, though, we were fine with it.  The entire cast did an excellent job, which just confirmed out belief that the arts should never be a competition.  Highly recommended.

A remarkable story about a very remarkable man.
Eddie  Redmayne gives an outstanding performance as Hawking, portraying him as he gradually progresses from a brash college student to a totally helpless cripple, but retains his brilliant intellect. Felicity Jones also delivers a moving performance as the woman who marries him, knowing his diagnosis and probable future, becomes the mother of his children, and then becomes his caregiver.
I always wondered why Hawking divorced Jane after she was so devoted to him all those years. The movie offers the explanation that he let her go to pursue a more normal life, and married his nurse, who had the skills to care for him. I guess that was not successful, either, as they also later divorced.

My husband is a physicist, so he especially enjoyed this movie.  As even though I understand practically nothing about Physics, it was well worth my viewing as well.  My husband went on to read the book, and he is very much enjoying it as well.

The problem with celebrity biopics is that you already know what's going to happen. This movie isn't great--it plods forward through Hawkings' life from one point to another point at the same steady pace. There's nothing suspenseful, and even his moments of insights seem pedestrian. The narrative avoids dwelling on his intellectual achievements, counting on his gradual physical decay to drive the story (ironically, in a very linear timeline). Redmayne (and no doubt there was a team behind him, helping him get the expressions and postures correct) deserves his accolades, though--it was easy to forget that he was an actor playing the part and that this wasn't somehow Hawking himself.

This man deserves every award he gets for this role. Amazing and inspiring story. I grew up with a life long disability and always like to see how it is portrayed in movies, and I love this movie. I don't want to create any spoilers. I found the ending disappointing but considering it's based on a true story, you can't blame the movie on that :). Highly recommended. This true story Oscar-winning film centers around the struggles of relationship and acceptance upon his ALS diagnosis by Dr. Stephen Hawking and his wife Jane. If you, like myself, are expecting to see more of a biographical take on Dr. Hawking's work and achievements as the world's eminent physicist, you may be let down. This story follows the story of Dr. Hawking (who is more than beautifully portrayed by Eddie Redmayne, who deserves every bit of his recent academy award for it) from an almost marriage counseling perspective as opposed to a celebration of his mind and contributions.  It illustrates the initial blossom of love, loyalty and dedication the couple has to their marriage, but also the trials, temptations and hardships associated with that relationship when life events suddenly and drastically change the face of each persons' world. It minimally focuses on Dr. Hawking's success and offers more screen time to his physical struggle with his disease and its' connection to his family.  A beautiful drama, well acted and worth it's acclaim, but nothing more than a typical storytelling of hardships some face in life.

The intense, heartstrong, tragic saga of Professor Stephen Hawking, who succeeds professionally despite the personal and physical tolls of an early-onset ALS diagnosis. It handles the subject remarkably well, placing us in the wheelchair right beside him throughout his physical descent. When he aches, struggling with staircases, obligations and words alike, we hurt along with him. We fall head over heels for Hawking's relationship with his young love, Jane Wilde, only to watch their spark slowly flicker amidst the trials of his condition and increasing social status. It's a bittersweet combination of enduring hope and crushing loss. Beautifully shot and superbly acted, particularly in the two lead roles, this is a wonderful encapsulation of the vibrancy of a life well-lived. Well worth watching, it's sure to move you in many different ways, and maybe even make you think twice about what you've unsuspectingly put your own loved ones through.

Inspiring movie about the life of Stephen Hawking told in a very uplifting way.  No car chases, no explosions, no "saving the world" moments-- just a great story told plainly. Eddie Redmayne and Felicity Jones are wonderful as Hawking and Jane (his wife).  The supporting cast is likewise uniformly excellent-- my minor quibble is that I would've liked to have found out more about the treatments he received during the first years of his illness (he was initially given only 2 years to live by doctors in 1964 or 65).  Overall a very good movie.-- recommended.

However, I do feel that it was a bit formulaic in showing the life story of a person with ALS and though I understand this was a major factor in Steven Hawking's life, I am not that interested in his struggles there, and I suspect neither is he. I would have liked the movie to focus more on his internal struggles (I assume there were many) with trying to prove his theories. Essentially, the story became more about his ALS than his achievements. Perhaps that was the intention all along? I guess I could watch a documentary to see the other things.

Truly extraordinary performances, especially from Eddie Redmayne. And wonderful recreation of the era. Such an incredible life as is Stephen Hawking that to accomplish all that film makers have done, from the full production team; screen-play, direction, cinematograpy, crew and cast, and the score. It was a bit romanticized, but does not fail Hawking in any way in his horrendous realization of the full prognosis and effects of motor neutron, and how, with Jane's determination and love, he overcame all odds, the inevitable dissolution of that marriage, his relentless research, which continues today, 52 years after he was told at 21 that he'd only 2 years to live. The film does not dwell on the anguish of the first marriage break-up and doesn't address at all the acrimony of his second. It is a concise brilliant study of this amazing man and is portrayed by a brilliant young actor.

I think this may be due to the movie dealing with touchy interpersonal relationship issues between two people who are actually still living. At times it seemed like the easy way out was for the film to gloss over the complexity of the issues. Still an excellent movie, all things considered.

Excellent movie with heartbreaking portrayals of two people who refused to let others define their potential for success.  Though difficult to watch at times, I was struck by the many themes covered such as how society looks away when others are disabled, and how many believe there is no other option for the disabled but to end their suffering, and therefore that of those who may love them.  This is a true love story, not neat, uplifting or romantic, but a portrayal of the deepest love one can imagine, and two people who defied the odds to find it.  I would recommending watching it with subtitles enabled, however, as some of Stephen Hawking's dialogue is difficult to understand once the ALS has taken hold, and you won't want to miss the wry, sensitive and charming humor of this amazing man.
This movie is so well done and acted it's hard to describe. I have followed this man for a long while but not this side of him. Well done on a large scale.

I would like to log a complaint about the Amazon movie streaming.  I watched this movie, and when the credits began, suddenly there was a menu covering up the bottom third of screening giving options for other movies I'd like to stream through Amazon.  And I could not get rid of it.  The credits were in the beginning title portions, where they list the main credits (they had not begun their scroll), and I actually enjoy sitting through them, but for the entirety of it, part of my screen was obscured by this menu.  I would like to make a request that this "feature" be removed (I wouldn't be selecting a title from such a menu anyway), otherwise, if I find this popping up in other movies, I will gladly use alternative streaming services.

Go watch this movie. It is really really superb.

Eddie Redmayne has been a powerful actor in "Birdsong" & "Pillars of the Earth," among others.  This is his best role yet, a remarkable embodiment -- not just a performance -- as Stephen Hawking.  The script is excellent & the entire film is enthralling, if you like BBC-types of stories & sets & period costumes.  However, the supporting cast is not on the same level as Redmayne; they're competent, but not brilliant and moving, as he is.  Wife # 1 is particularly dull & miscast, but soon-to-be Wife # 2 is the best of the lot, as is David Thewlis as his professor, later his colleague. Be sure to watch the entire closing credits which will catapult you into the beauty & rapture of outer space & remind you of your infinite capabilities.

Dr. Hawking is a fascinating character, as most truly brilliant people are. This movie is not so much about his science and his theories as it is about his life and his personality, and watching Eddie Redmayne portray Hawking is worth twice the price of admission. For me, the mark of a good movie is catching myself thinking about it for days or weeks afterwards, and "The Theory of Everything has lingered in my head ever since I watched it.

This is a terrifically entertaining and emotional film from start to finish. His sense of humour comes across very well. Redmayne's portrayal makes him very likeable. I am not sure if this is because Redmayne is a sweet, nice chap or if Hawking is as well. It is entertaining nonetheless. I truly don't know how Redmayne managed to pull off the disabilities and how much was down to computer wizardry but it is still pretty amazing and realistic. The only negative for me was Jane falling in love with the simpering wimp Jonathan - I am not sure of course if the real life Jonathan is the same having never met him. I thought the way he ended up with Jane was a little ungallant and cowardly and that reflects badly on Jane's character too for me.

I know I will be in the minority here but I cannot a good conscious give this movie a great review. I am a huge Stephen Hawking fan and while I definitely believe that the best actor Oscar should go to this movie I also believe one should not confuse a great performance with a great film.

In my view this is a tragic missed opportunity to tell an amazing story. The scenes here are rapidfire one after the next and tell an almost movie-of-the-week like biopic treatment of Mr. Hawking's life. There is virtually no drama or conflict and at no point do I feel like I am sitting on the edge of my seat wondering "oh my God how is he going to get out of this?"

I kind of get the feeling like one is almost not allowed to give this movie a bad review because to do so is to somehow be disparaging of Mr. Hawking himself. But I'm going to risk that pie in the face and say that indeed the emperor here is naked. Mr. Hawkins is a great physicist who has contributed great things to this world. It is unfortunate that Hollywood could not use it skills to produce a movie that matches his contributions.

If you have no knowledge or background on Mr. Hawking's life and want to see a wrote, pat, description of the progression of his life then this movie is a good place to start. However, if you are looking for deep intellectual insight into what it is like to be a person who suffers a serious physical disability on the outside while having the mind of God on the inside, well, then this movie is going to disappoint you. It offers no spiritual insight whatsoever.

The Oscars have been awarded and Eddie Redmayne won Best Actor for his astonishingly fine performance as Stephen Hawking. For those interested in learning more about the extraordinary mind of this physicist and his contributions to science, do not expect to be enlightened. The story is more a love story adapted from his first wife Jane Hawking's book TRAVELING TO INFINITY: MY LIFE WITH STEPHEN  as adapted for the screen by Anthony McCarten. Were it not for the struggle with ALS that is depicted from the onset to the present (Hawking is 72 years old at present) and the manner in which both Hawking and Jane adjusted to this deteriorating disease, this could have been another soap opera a la Nicholas Sparks, but the actors involved make it work, aided of course by the direction of James Marsh.

One summary offers the synopsis well: `The Theory of Everything is the story of the most brilliant and celebrated physicist of our time, Stephen Hawking (Eddie Redmayne) , and Jane Wilde (Felicity Jones) the arts student he fell in love with whilst studying at Cambridge in the 1960s. Little was expected from Stephen Hawking, a bright but shiftless student of cosmology, given just two years to live following the diagnosis of a fatal illness at 21 years of age. He became galvanized, however, by the love of fellow Cambridge student, Jane Wilde, and he went on to be called the successor to Einstein, as well as a husband and father to their three children. Over the course of their marriage as Stephen's body collapsed and his academic renown soared, fault lines were exposed that tested the lineaments of their relationship and dramatically altered the course of both of their lives: Stephen remarried Elaine mason (Maxine Peake) and Jane remarried Jonathan Hellyer Jones (the very fine actor Charlie Cox). The others in the large cast who deserve mention include David Thwelis as Stephen mentor and friend, Simon McBurney as Stephen's father, and a quick little walk on by Emily Watson.

The film does not fail to touch us because of the diagnosis and the performances, but it would have been stronger had more of Hawking's contributions been shared. Grady Harp, February 15

I cannot say enough about this fantastic movie.  The acting is nothing short of superior and the subject, Stephen Hawking, who I really believe is the most intelligent man on the planet, is absolutely brilliant in every way.  His challenges would have been insurmountable for any mere human being.  He found a way to persevere, and the world is a better place because of it.  Eddie Redmayne, who plays Hawking has been nominated for Best Actor for the Oscar as well as the Golden Globes.  Felicity Jones, who plays his long suffering wife, is also nominated for Best Actress for the Oscar as well as the Golden Globes.  The movie has already received many other awards.  They both deserve all the awards in the world.  Please do yourself a favor and watch this incredible movie.  And be prepared to be amazed at how they took a brilliant scientist and demonstrated that he is also an incredible human being who experienced a full private life.  He loved, he lived, he learned, he made mistakes just like everyone else.  I've always respected the man, now I love him.

Truly enjoyed this film -  now I want to know more about Sir Stephen Hawking, tho I don't understand the physics behind his theories!

I must admit I never paid much attention to Hawking until he appeared and was referenced to frequently in "The Big Bang Theory" and he began to intrigue me so I was eager to get the movie when it came out.  It made him really come to life.  It begins with him as a young man in college who falls in love with a woman and then receives what seems to be a death sentence.  I'm not a big crier, but I kept finding my throat tightening and my eyes getting teary at what that remarkable man went through and even more how much his wife loved and supported him.  There aren't many minds like his, it's true.  But there don't seem to be many women who have the strength and deep love like Jan did.

At the end be is listed at being 72 years old.  At the age of 20 or 21, he was given 2 years to live.  I really think that wouldn't have happened without Jane loving him and helping him and fighting so hard for him.

Yes, this is about Stephen, but Jane is the one who really shines through.

Eddie Redmayne and Felicity Jones have done an incredible job in portraying these two remarkable people.

Good films can hold my attention even when I have very little interest in the subject matter. I'm sure that most people have heard of Stephen Hawking, but I doubt that many of us think too deeply about what he has achieved. His synthesized voice appeared on Pink Floyd's Division Bell and he featured on an episode of Star Trek Next Generation, but what is he like as a person?

The Theory of Everything answers that question and provides insight about how life would be if we lost the power to walk and talk without mechanical assistance.

You might imagine that Hawking's story is dry and boring. After all, he's a scientist, and they just think about mathematics, don't they? I am happy to say that this film deserves its five Oscar nominations and is anything but boring. At its very heart, The Theory of Everything is a romance, but this is a moving story with moments of comedy. By the end of the film, you will be inspired and uplifted, if you care about any other human beings at all.

At the beginning of the film, Hawking (Redmayne) is young and socially awkward. He meets Jane (Jones) at a party and gets her phone number. He's obviously intelligent, but it's his charm that impresses Jane. Redmayne's performance shows Hawking as a likeable and humorous man. When we learn of his disease, we feel something. However, Jane is not deterred by his gloomy prognosis. The two decide to marry and make the most of whatever time they can have together.

Time is another important theme in the story. As Hawking impresses his Cambridge University professor (Thewlis) with his theories about time and the universe, I couldn't help contemplating my own existence. The film made me realize that everyone has a chance to contribute something to the world. In some ways I feel ashamed that I have wasted much of my own life with trivial matters.

I won't reveal any more of the story, but I want to emphasize how good the film is. It made me think of The King's Speech and The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, and that's a huge compliment. Jones and Redmayne have good chemistry and their relationship seems real.

If you are worried that the subject matter may be too depressing, I think it's safe to say that the overall feel is uplifting. Yes, you will see some of Hawking's struggles, but you'll also understand the immensity of his achievements.

Where there is life, there is hope.

Hawking reportedly approves of the film and commented that Redmayne's performance was so good that he felt he was seeing himself on the screen. I have to agree that it is an excellent performance.

Too many movies cater to audiences that demand instant gratification and thrills. The Theory of Everything will make you think and feel something. Ultimately, you will remember the story and take something from it if you are the type of person who likes to think beyond the immediate moment.

Overall score 4.5/5

"The Theory of Everything"is a beautiful story of love, brilliance, resilience, loss and forgiveness. Whether or not the Stephen Hawking character finds out about his disease in a fall in a hall or, as reported, elsewhere is of little consequence.  The important thing is terrific acting that shows us what the real Stephen Hawking must have felt.  It is through brilliant character development that viewers can vicariously experience how tragedy can be conquered by powerful thinking and brave determination.  I hope the actors, particularly, Eddie Redmayne are recognized for
this tour de force.

Aside from my raves for the acting and, I should mention as well, the fine  writing of the book and script, it was tremendously refreshing to see a film that is not about killing, hate, gratuitous violence and men in silly costumes that belie reality or girls trying to catch a man or vice versa.  I'm happy to go to the theatre to see  science made understandable and even sexy instead of being dumbed down by a date film or, as I said, a glorification of violence.

Well done, Hollywood.  Thanks for this one.

It took half a movie but when Eddie Redmayne changed on screen and the touching moments of his transformation and succeeding in life subsequently - that's when I saw it. James Marsh directs from the screenplay (Anthony McCarten) which is based on the book by Jane Hawking; "Traveling to Infinity: My Life With Stephen". The movie concentrates heavily on their short courtship and subsequent marriage along with all that they endure together in their relationship. Meeting at a party at Cambridge in 1963, the chemistry between Stephen Hawking (Eddie Redmayne), a cosmologist, English theoretical physicist and author who is then trying to prove that the universe has a beginning and an end, and Jane Wilde (Felicity Jones), studying medieval Spanish poetry, was clear to see. While this film explains the story of their family connections from Jane's point of view, I found it to be a love story straight away. We are only shown a short romance before their marriage although it is quite clear where they are heading.

It is at the age of twenty-one that symptoms are beginning to be displayed in Stephen conducive to his early diagnosis similar to ALS (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis). Like Lou Gehrig's Disease which is a complicated motor neuron degeneration causing havoc within his body and a myriad of manifestations. His voluntary muscles begin to corrupt and wither, then most of his movement does become uncontrollable; swallowing, talking, walking, anything that would involve manual dexterity, even breathing are all affected. Along with many other issues, this will include paralysis. Before long, Stephen Hawking is wheelchair bound and is in need of constant care. His mind is not affected whatsoever which makes for the frustrating state of being aware of what is happening to his body without having the ability to do anything about it. When diagnosed, he is given a prognosis of two years although Stephen Hawking is quite exceptional. He doesn't show anger or volatility, but a constant amiable personality along with an ease in what could be humorous situations for him. Eddie Redmayne demonstrates this brilliantly, possibly the best physical portrayal that I have seen.

While Stephen's father tells Jane at the time that "This is going to be a very heavy defeat for all of us", Jane reassures Stephen, "No matter how much time we've got, we will spend it together". Apparently, Jane is made of much tougher stuff than had been believed of her at first. Stephen now changes his concentration of study to the 'Theory of Everything' and a universe without boundaries. This couple moves through having three children together, defying the odds year after year and building a bond with the love that they share, no matter how rocky the family unit does get. I could go on about all of the content in the movie, but it is far better to view for yourself the family life of the Hawkings.

Eddie Redmayne is absolutely dynamic portraying Stephen Hawking, his all-consuming portrayal deserves so much praise. A scene at the end of the film just blew me away. An imagining by Hawking shows he is able to do something that is physically impossible at the time which made it all the more astounding and beautiful to behold. Felicity Jones portrays a wife who goes through the changes by making the necessary adjustments including all of the stages that take place with her husband and in her private life. Definitely a real-life and emotional love story as I viewed it, including the fullness of lush music (Jóhann Jóhannsson) that rises and swells at all the right times. This will have you thinking about these performances for a long, long time ... Simply Incredible.
A tad slow at the beginning but definitely worth the watch. I am glad I bought it - I will watch again!
